(B)  Other automatic extinguishing systems shall be required in occupancies where the use of water sprinklers may be hazardous. These areas shall be defined but not limited to electrical equipment rooms, meter rooms where electrical switch gear is used, elevator equipment rooms or any other areas determined to be hazardous by the authority having jurisdiction. Such systems shall be approved by the authority having jurisdiction. 
(C)  Buildings equipped with automatic extinguishing systems (i.e., fire sprinkler systems, Halon systems, dry chemical systems, etc.) shall have a maintenance agreement with a certified contractor and shall have performed an annual test of these systems to include fire pumps where provided. Copies of the maintenance agreement and annual tests shall be on file with the authority having jurisdiction. 
(1)  Existing automatic extinguishing systems shall also be included under these agreements. 
(Ord. 81-29, passed 9-2-81; Am. Ord. 86-7, passed 4-7-86; Am. Ord. 89-04, passed 3-6-89) 
Cross reference- Penalty, § 94.99 
94.47 - Standpipes required. 
(A)  New and existing buildings with three stories or more and any other structures that in the opinion of the authority having jurisdiction are inaccessible to firefighting equipment, shall be equipped with standpipes and 21/2-inch valved fire department hose connections at each floor level, in accordance with NFPA-14 except as modified by subsection (1) of this section. 
(1)  Existing buildings required by this section to install standpipes, shall install the dry pipe type system and shall not be required to install fire pumps unless fire sprinkler systems are also required by other sections of this Code. 
(B)  All 21/2-inch valved fire department hose connections with or without hoses shall be located in the exit access within ten feet of the exit door. Valves without hoses shall be installed not less than three feet or more than five feet above the floor as directed by the authority having jurisdiction. 
(C)  Both standpipe and sprinkler systems shall be provided with individual Siamese fire department pumper connections. Where individual systems are present, fire department connections will be marked as to system. 
(D)  Combination standpipe and sprinkler system risers as allowed by this chapter will be permitted under the following conditions: 
(1)  Each take-off from the riser to the sprinkler system shall be provided with a supervised shutoff valve as directed but not more than seven feet above the floor. 
(2)  Buildings ten stories or more in height shall be provided with an auxiliary Class I standpipe in parallel with the fire sprinkler riser. This standpipe shall be provided with a 21/2-inch valved fire department hose connection at each floor next to those required by subsection (B) of this section, and shall be clearly labeled "auxiliary system". Each auxiliary standpipe shall be provided with a fire department pumper connection and shall be pressurized from the main system through a one-inch, properly checked, pipe connection. 
(E)  The water supply for standpipes or sprinkler systems shall meet the requirements of the N.F.P.A. for minimum acceptable flow and residual pressure; however, the authority having jurisdiction may increase these minimum requirements if the factors in the N.F.PA. warrant. 
(F)  All electrically driven or started pumps required to ensure adequate flow and pressure in the standpipe and sprinkler system shall be connected to the emergency power system as described in section 94.50. 
(G)  All fire pumps shall bear the seal of a nationally recognized independent testing agency. Where two or more standpipes or combination risers are installed in the same building, they shall be interconnected "full size" at the bottom and at the tenth floor. Additional interconnections shall be provided above the tenth floor at a minimum of five and a maximum of every ten floors. Auxiliary standpipes need not be interconnected. All interconnections shall be valved at each standpipe. 
(H)  Where fire pumps are required, a single-function pressure maintenance pump shall be installed to maintain pressure on the fire sprinkler and standpipe system only. 
(1)  Existing buildings equipped with fire pumps shall also comply with this section. 
(I)  Buildings required under this section to have standpipe systems shall have a maintenance agreement with a certified contractor who shall be required to perform an annual test of these systems. Copies of the maintenance agreement and tests shall be on file with the authority having jurisdiction. 
(J)  Compliance timetable: Existing buildings required to comply with this section shall do so by April 7, 1989. 
(Ord. 81-29, passed 9-2-81; Am. Ord. 86-7, passed 4-7-86; Am. Ord. 88-13, passed 5-2-88) 
Cross reference- Penalty, § 94.99 
94.48 - Alarm annunciator. 
(A)  The fire alarm annunciator panel shall be located at the main entrance to the building at a position approved by the authority having jurisdiction. In cases where the main building entrance is not an adequate entrance for firefighting equipment, the annunciator shall be located as directed by the authority having jurisdiction. 
(B)  The annunciator shall consist of pilot lights or drop flags and be equipped with a permanent engraved directory. The wording and information of the directory shall be approved by the authority having jurisdiction. 
(C)  The annunciator shall be connected to individual apartments and all common areas or as otherwise directed by the authority having jurisdiction. 
(D)  All structures required by this Code to install alarm annunciators shall install for fire department use a public address system in all common areas with transmitting capabilities at the annunciator panel. The system shall be capable of silencing alarm-sounding devices when transmitting. 
(Ord. 81-29, passed 9-2-81; Am. Ord. 86-7, passed 4-7-86; Ord. 89-04, 3-6-89) 
Cross reference- Penalty, § 94.99 
94.49 - Fire station connections. 
    Fire station connections shall be such as to automatically notify the fire department at the same time the automatic alarm system is activated. The method of notifying the fire department shall be through a V.L. Central Station approved by the authority having jurisdiction. 
(Ord. 81-29, passed 9-2-81; Am. Ord. 92-08, passed 3-3-92) 
Cross reference- Penalty, § 94.99 
94.50 - Emergency electrical power. 
(A)  Emergency electrical power shall be so arranged as to provide the required power for lighting and emergency equipment automatically in the event of failure of the normal power. Emergency electrical power shall be either continuously in operation, or shall be capable of repeated automatic operation without manual intervention, for a period of not less than 90 minutes. 
(B)  Emergency electrical power subject to the approval of the authority having jurisdiction may be provided by any method or combination of methods as follows: 
(1)  Two separate electrical systems, each adequate alone to provide the necessary power, one supplied from an outside source such as a public utility service, and the other from an electric generator on the premises driven by an independent energy source, shall be in regular simultaneous operation whenever the building is occupied. 
(2)  An electrical circuit or circuits used only for emergency power with two independent electric energy sources so arranged that on the failure of one, the other will come automatically and immediately into operation. One such independent source shall be a connection from a public utility or similar outside power source, and the other shall be one of the following: 
(a)  An approved storage battery with suitable provisions to keep it automatically charged. The battery shall also be provided with automatic controls so that after the battery comes into operation due to turning off the primary electrical power source, it will be shut off after its period of operation and will be ready for further service when the primary electrical power is again turned on. 
1.  Emergency power required in these provisions for elevators and fire pumps shall not be provided by battery storage systems. See section 94.52. 
(b)  The other power source may be an electrical generator set provided and maintained according to the provisions of Article 700 of the National Electrical Code adopted by the town (see § 94.03.) When emergency generators are required, no less than two generators shall be used for a development. No emergency generator can service more than one building without a backup generator. 
    NOTE: These generators shall be interconnected and sized for the entire development. 
(c)  Unit devices with approved individual batteries providing for the same functions as specified above, except that the battery-supplied light may be operated on a separate circuit at a voltage different from that of the primary light, provided the unit battery-powered devices are installed and maintained according to Underwriter's Laboratories listing. 
(d)  The primary source of electrical power for exit lighting, exit signs, and exit access lighting shall be connected ahead of the main building disconnect switch. 
(e)  An emergency source of electrical power is not required for internally illuminated exit signs provided the exit sign is externally illuminated by one of the approved methods listed in this chapter and the sign's readability meets the requirements of the standard building code. 
(f)  Emergency electrical power is required for all exit and exit access lighting by one or more of the approved methods listed in this section. 
(g)  All emergency generators shall be equipped with an automatic timer to test said generators on a weekly basis as per manufacturer's recommendation. 
1.  This shall also apply to all existing buildings equipped with emergency generators. 
(Ord. 81-29, passed 9-2-81; Am. Ord. 86-7, passed 4-7-86) 
Cross reference- Penalty, § 94.99 
94.51 - Construction design requirements. 
(A)  One elevator in each bank shall be electrically wired in order to provide the fire department with complete control. Directions detailing operation shall be installed within the elevator car. 
(B)  All buildings with elevator accommodations shall also have an automatic emergency power source to provide electrical power in order to operate elevators and all emergency equipment. 
(1)  In developments where emergency generators are required because of elevators, the number of elevators to operate simultaneously shall be determined by the authority having jurisdiction, after considering the size of the development. 
(C)  Enclosed stairwells connected to enclosed corridors or vestibules shall be pressurized according to the requirements of the standard building code. Pressurization systems, smoke and vapor removal systems, and command control centers shall be required to have a certified test prior to a certificate of occupancy being issued. Copies of certified tests are to be on file with the authority having jurisdiction. 
(D)  Single-family structures and duplexes with parking facilities below the structure shall have a minimum of one-hour fire protection, as defined by the current standard building code between the parking facility and the first floor of the structure. 
(E)  This section does not apply to elevators that are used exclusively for private individual use unless specifically required by the authority having jurisdiction. 
(Ord. 81-29, passed 9-2-81; Am. Ord. 86-7, passed 4-7-86) 
Cross reference- Penalty, § 94.99 
Cross reference- Adoption of the standard building code, § 150.01. 
94.52 - Alternative electric and water supply systems. 
    Where more than one building is located in an area that can be adequately serviced by a single emergency power system or water supply system, then the authority having jurisdiction shall have the right to waive the foregoing requirements of an individual power and water supply system for each building and may permit, in lieu thereof, a water supply or electrical power system shown to be capable of adequately servicing several buildings. 
(Ord. 81-29, passed 9-2-81) 
Cross reference- Penalty, § 94.99 
Emergency Medical Aid Fees 

94.55 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of § 94.56, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
(A)  "Emergency nontransport." Means emergency aid and resuscitation of a sick or injured person at the scene of an accident or medical emergency without transportation or removal to a hospital. 
(B)  "Emergency transport." Means emergency aid and resuscitation of a sick or injured person at the scene of an accident or medical emergency and subsequent transportation under emergency vehicle procedures where it appears that the physical condition of the person is such as to require immediate and expeditious removal to a hospital. The transporting of an expectant mother, when it is evident that birth is imminent, shall also be considered an emergency transport. 
(C)  "Loaded mile." Means a mile of ambulance operation when the ambulance is actually occupied by the patient. 
(D)  "Patient." Means an individual who is ill, sick, injured, wounded or otherwise appears incapacitated or helpless. 
(E)  "Resident." Means one who is a domiciliary of the Town of Longboat Key. Proof of domicile may be established only by the production of a Florida driver's license, voter's registration card, or recorded declaration of domicile showing Longboat Key as the permanent address of the person declaring domicile. 
(Ord. 87-27, passed 9-24-87) 
94.56 - Emergency transport fees. 
    The emergency transport fees shall be set by resolution of the town commission. Treatment shall be rendered regardless of the patient's ability to pay. The town manager may waive the fees set forth if the patient clearly establishes his inability to pay. 
(Ord. 87-27, passed 9-24-87; Amd. Ord. 90-27, passed 10-8-90; Amd. Ord. 92-08, passed 3-3-92; Amd. Ord. 01-11, passed 7-2-01; Amd. Ord. 04-05, passed 3-1-04) 
94.99 - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter for which another penalty is not provided, or shall fail to comply therewith; or shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder; or shall build in violation of any details, statements, specifications, or plans submitted or approved thereunder; or shall operate not in accordance with the provisions of any certificate, permit, or approval issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken; or who shall fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified by the authority having jurisdiction or by a court of competent jurisdiction within the time fixed herein shall severally for each and every violation and noncompliance, respectively be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00 or by imprisonment for not more than 60 days with each day of the violation constituting a separate offense. The imposition of a penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation, nor shall the violation be permitted to continue. All persons shall be required to correct or remedy the violations or defects within a reasonable time and when not otherwise specified, the application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
(Ord. 81-29, passed 9-2-81; Amd. Ord. 83-1, passed 2-2-83) 
Chapter 95 - GARBAGE, RUBBISH, JUNK AND RECYCLING* 
Collection Regulations 

95.01 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this subchapter the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    "Food and industrial processing wastes." The waste products of canneries, slaughterhouses, packing plants, large quantities of condemned food products, industrial wastes from brick, concrete block, roofing shingle, or tile plants, debris and wastes accumulated from land clearing, building, rebuilding, and altering or buildings, structures, roads, streets, sidewalks, parkways, excavating by an owner, contractor, or work performed by purchase and hire of labor and materials. 
    "Garbage." Every refuse accumulation of animal, fruit, or vegetable matter that attends the preparation, use, cooking, and dealing in, or storage of, meats, fish, fowl, fruit, or vegetables, and any other matter of any nature whatsoever which is subject to decay, putrefaction, and the generation of noxious or offensive gases or odors, or which during or after decay, may serve as breeding or feeding materials for flies or other germ-carrying insects; and any bottles, cans, or other containers which, due to their ability to retain water, may serve as breeding places for mosquitoes or other water-breeding insects. 
    "Garbage can." A galvanized iron or plastic can of the type commonly sold as a garbage can of a capacity not to exceed 32 gallons. The can shall have two handles on the sides of the can, or bail by which it may be lifted, and shall have a tight-fitting top. 
    "Garden trash." All accumulations of grass or shrubbery cuttings, and other refuse attending the care of lawns, shrubbery, vines, trees, and tree limbs. 
    "Multiple dwellings." All places of abode other than single-family residences, including garage apartments, duplex residences, apartment houses, rooming or boardinghouses, sanitariums, rest homes, resident schools, hotels, motor courts, guesthouses, tourist homes, trailer courts and trailer camps, and other similar or like places. 
    "Noncombustible refuse." Refuse materials that are unburnable at ordinary incinerator temperature (800°F. to 1800°F.) such as metals, mineral matter, large quantities of glass or crockery, metal furniture, auto bodies or parts, and other similar materials or refuse not usual to housekeeping or to operation of stores or offices. 
    "Rubbish." Refuse accumulations of paper, excelsior, rags, wooden or paper boxes or containers, sweepings, and all other accumulations of a nature other than "garbage" as defined above which are usual to housekeeping and to the operation of stores, offices, and other business places; and materials such as metals, mineral mater, glass, crockery, auto bodies or parts, including automobile tires or tubes, building material rubble resulting from the construction or alteration of structures or parts of structures, and other materials or refuse not usual to housekeeping or the operation of stores and offices. 
    "Trash." Refuse accumulations of paper, excelsior, rags, wooden or paper boxes or containers, sweepings, and all other accumulations of a nature other than garbage, which are usual to housekeeping and to the operations of stores, offices, and other business places. "Trash" shall not include "noncombustible refuse," nor "garden trash," as defined above. 
    "Trash container." The same as defined above as "garbage can"; provided, however, that by a special permit issued by the director of public works, a "trash container" may be of different specifications or design. 
('71 Code, § 10-1; Ord. 129, passed 8-8-67; Amd. Ord. 139, passed 7-9-68; Ord. 80-7, passed 9-15-80; Amd. Ord. 03-13, passed 7-7-03) 
95.02 - Garbage and trash receptacles. 
    All residents or occupants of any single-family dwelling, and the owner, manager, or occupant of any multiple dwelling or of any place of business or commercial establishment within the town are hereby required to provide a garbage can and trash can, as defined in section 95.01; however, no garbage can or trash can shall be over the capacity of 32 gallons, except upon permit of the director of public works. The owner or manager of any multiple dwelling shall furnish or see that the multiple dwelling is furnished or supplied with a sufficient number of garbage and trash cans to comply with this section, or multiple family and commercial establishments may use a bulk container as authorized by the town's franchised refuse disposal organization. No receptacle used for the storage of refuse, except mechanically dumped containers, may exceed a capacity of 32 gallons. 
(Ord. 80-7, passed 9-15-80) 
Cross reference- Penalty, § 95.99 
95.03 - Duty to provide refuse containers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who is responsible to provide refuse containers to fail to provide and maintain them in sufficient numbers and in serviceable condition for disposal of refuse accumulations for disposal services on a basis of two times each week. Where provision for disposal of garbage and trash has been made on a basis providing for disposal more frequently than two times each week, then it shall be unlawful for any person responsible to provide refuse containers, to fail to provide them in sufficient numbers for disposal of garbage and trash accumulations for the period between the regularly-scheduled collections. 
(Ord. 80-7, passed 9-15-80) 
Cross reference- Penalty, § 95.99 
95.04 - Location, inspection of refuse containers. 
(A)  All privately-owned refuse containers shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition by the owner, and maintained in a place readily accessible for pickup. 
(B)  All refuse containers shall be subject to inspection and approval or condemnation by the director or his authorized inspectors. 
(Ord. 80-7, passed 9-15-80; Amd. Ord. 03-13, passed 7-7-03) 
Cross reference- Penalty, § 95.99 
95.05 - Garbage to be collected by town; exceptions. 
(A)  It shall be unlawful for any garbage or trash to be removed by or disposed of by persons other than the town's franchised refuse disposal organization, unless a permit therefor has been obtained from the director of public works to permit removal of garbage or trash by a special permittee of the town. An application for a permit must specify the type of vehicle in which it is to be transported, and the location and manner of the ultimate disposition of the garbage or trash. The type of vehicle in which it is to be transported, and the location and manner of the ultimate disposition of the garbage or trash, must comply with the provisions of this subchapter. 
(B)  It shall be the responsibility of the owners, operators, contractors, and custodians to remove or cause to be removed food and industrial wastes as defined in section 95.01, large tree stumps, spent oils and grease, unburnable metals, mineral matter, large quantities of glass or crockery, metal furniture, auto bodies or parts, and other similar materials in accordance with the provisions of this subchapter wherever and to the extent that any persons cause these wastes to accumulate. 
(Ord. 80-7, passed 9-15-80) 
Cross reference- Penalty, § 95.99 
95.06 - Preparation of refuse for collection. 
(A)  Highly inflammable or explosive materials shall not be placed in containers for regular collections but shall be disposed of as directed by the director of public works. Human and animal wastes shall not be placed in refuse containers intended for collection. 
(B)  All occupants of abode and all owners, managers, or custodians of businesses and institutions shall deposit or cause to be deposited all garbage and trash in accordance with the methods prescribed in this subchapter in containers complying with provisions of section 95.02. All garbage shall first be drained of all liquids and shall be deposited daily in refuse containers, with wet garbage being placed in paper, plastic, or polyethylene bags or securely wrapped in paper before being placed in the containers. Hotels and restaurants and other eating establishments shall be required to wrap wet garbage unless exempted by the director. Pasteboard boxes shall be collapsed prior to being placed in refuse containers. Refuse containers shall be kept tightly covered at all times except when uncovered for purposes of depositing refuse. 
(Ord. 80-7, passed 9-15-80; Amd. 03-13, passed 7-7-03) 
Cross reference- Penalty, § 95.99 
95.07 - Collection times. 
    All refuse containers shall be emptied in accordance with the franchise agreement promulgated by the town for the collection of refuse and recyclable materials. 
(Ord. 80-7, passed 9-15-80; Amd. Ord. 03-13, passed 7-7-03) 
95.08 - Fees, billing for town refuse service. 
(A)  All fees to be charged shall be in accordance with the then applicable franchise agreement for such services as may be amended. 
(B)  All payments for removal of refuse shall be on a current basis. Bills for regularly scheduled collections of containerized refuse will be rendered by the town or the town's franchised refuse collection organization. Where the town is responsible for billing, and the customer is also a town water customer, the charge for the service shall be billed on the same bill as that containing the statement for water and sewer charges. Receipts for refuse collection service shall be issued by the office or department originating the billing and receiving the payment for the services. The receipts shall be in the form that shall be prescribed by the finance director. 
(Ord. 80-7, passed 9-15-80; Amd. Res. 81-29, passed 10-7-81; Amd. Res. 83-10, passed 3-2-83; Amd. Res. 88-35, passed 10-3-88; Amd. Ord. 03-13, passed 7-7-03) 
Cross reference- Penalty, § 95.99 
Garbage, Ashes and Filth 

95.15 - Policy. 
    It is the declared policy of the town that the pollution of the atmosphere by smoke, fly ash, products of complete or incomplete combustion, and certain other emissions into the atmosphere; the discharge of untreated or inadequately treated sewerage or sewerage effluent into the waters within the jurisdiction of the town; or the discarding of garden trash, garbage, or brush on the lands or waters within the municipal boundaries of the town, is a menace to the welfare and comfort of the people of the town and a cause of extensive damage to health and property. The necessity for legislative intervention by the enactment of the provisions of this subchapter is for the purpose of controlling and reducing atmospheric pollution and the pollution of the land and its adjacent waters. 
('71 Code, § 10-2) (Ord. 129, passed 8-8-67) 
Cross reference- Pollution control, §§ 96.45 and 96.46. 
95.16 - Unlawful deposits. 
    It shall be unlawful: 
(A)  For any person to place or deposit garbage, garden trash, brush, or rubbish on the premises of another, whether the premises are improved or vacant, or on any street, alley, park, road or rock pit, pool, lake, or any of the tidal waters of the Gulf of Mexico or the bays and bayous within or adjacent to the town; 
(B)  For any person to intentionally cause grass clippings, vegetative material, or vegetative debris to be washed, swept, deposited, blown, placed, or moved into drains, ditches, conveyances, canals, or any other waterbody connected to or part of Sarasota Bay, its' passes, or the Gulf of Mexico, or upon any street or roadway within the town; or 
(C)  For any person to fail to exercise reasonable care which causes grass clippings, vegetative material, or vegetative debris to be washed, swept, deposited, blown, placed, or moved into drains, ditches, conveyances, canals, or any other waterbody connected to or part of Sarasota Bay, its' passes, or the Gulf of Mexico, or upon any street or roadway within the town. 
('71 Code, § 10-3; Ord. 129, passed 8-8-67; Amd. Ord. 08-07, passed 4-7-08) 
Cross reference- Penalty, § 95.99; disposal of garbage from boats, § 93.16. 
95.17 - Throwing, spilling refuse from vehicles. 
(A)  The driver of any motor vehicle from which any garbage, garden trash, or rubbish is thrown, ejected, or emitted shall be prima facie guilty of a violation of this subchapter. 
(B)  It shall be unlawful for any person to transport on any public roads within the town, garbage, refuse, trash, rubbish, sand, soil, gravel, shell, rock, marl, limestone, or asphalt in a vehicle which is not completely covered or otherwise secured in such a manner as to prevent the spilling of its contents on public roads. It shall be unlawful for any person to transport on any public roads within the town material or supplies other than those enumerated herein in a vehicle which is not completely covered or otherwise properly secured in such a manner as to prevent the spilling of its contents on public roads. 
('71 Code, §§ 10-4, 10-7; Ord. 129, passed 8-8-67; Amd. Ord. 178, passed 9-16-70) 
Cross reference- Penalty, § 95.99 
95.18 - Burning or burying rubbish. 
    The burning or burying of garbage or rubbish is prohibited. 
('71 Code, § 10-5; Ord. 129, passed 8-8-67; Amd. Ord. 73-1, passed 1-10-73) 
Cross reference- Penalty, § 95.99 
Junk, Discarded Materials and Containers 

95.25 - Accumulations prohibited; exceptions. 
(A)  For the purpose of this section the following definition shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    "Junk." Wrecked or abandoned cars, abandoned equipment, rags, abandoned mattresses, abandoned iceboxes or refrigerators, abandoned stoves, abandoned beds and bed springs, and abandoned obsolescent machinery or metal objects, singularly or collectively, in whole or part. 
(B)  It shall be unlawful to accumulate, park, store, or allow the accumulation, parking, or storing of any junk, as junk is herein defined, within the town, unless authorized in conjunction with a business properly operated pursuant to the zoning ordinances of the town. 
(C)  It shall be unlawful to park, openly store, or allow the accumulation of boats, boat trailers, cars, trucks, motorcycles, motor scooters or tractors not displaying a current license plate and not having a current state registration, or lawn mowers, machinery or appliances that are visible from a street unless authorized in conjunction with a business properly operated pursuant to the zoning ordinances of the town. 
(D)  Boats, boat trailers, cars, truck, motorcycles, motor scooters or tractors having current license plates and state registration can be parked or stored in compliance with § 158.128 of the Town of Longboat Key Zoning Code or other applicable provision of the Town Code. 
(E)  All containers for junk, solid waste, yard waste and recycling, placed within the public right-of-way or within five feet of the public right-of-way, shall be removed or otherwise effaced from public view within 48 hours of placement. 
('71 Code, §§ 14-16, 14-17; Ord. 227, passed 8-23-72; Amd. Ord. 88-17, passed 4-19-88; Amd. Ord. 96-27, passed 1-6-97; Amd. Ord. 03-13, passed 7-7-03) 
95.26 - Resolution authorizing removal. 
    Whenever it shall become apparent to the town commission that there are properties in the town on which there is junk as defined in subsection 95.25(A), it may adopt a resolution instructing the town manager to forthwith proceed with the removal, clearing away, elimination, and disposal of the junk in the manner specified herein. 
('71 Code, § 14-18; Ord. 227, passed 8-23-72) 
95.27 - Removal notice. 
(A)  The town manager, promptly after the adoption of the resolution, shall give written notice to the owners and any known agents, custodians, lessees, or occupants of any property on which there is junk as defined in subsection 95.25(A), to remove, clear away, eliminate, and dispose of the junk in not more than 15 days from the receipt of the notice. The notice shall describe the property affected and state the name of the owner of the real estate on which the junk is situated, or the person in which the real estate was last assessed, as this appears from the tax records of the town, and shall state that if the owner or person last assessed or someone in his behalf shall not proceed to remove the junk from the property within the time specified in the notice, the town may proceed to do the work and to assess the cost thereof against the real property from which the junk was removed. 
(B)  The notice shall be given in the first instance either by registered or certified mail, with return receipt requested, or by personal delivery of the notice. Personal delivery may be made by any person of the age of 21 years or more, with proof of delivery thereof being made by a sworn affidavit. In the event the town manager is unable, after reasonable diligence, to give the notice, then it may be given by publishing the notice at least one time in a daily newspaper of general circulation in the town. In the event a notice is first attempted to be given by mail, as aforesaid and the receipt of delivery is not returned showing delivery within ten days after the mailing thereof, the town manager shall be deemed to have exercised reasonable diligence and shall thereafter be directed to proceed by publication as herein provided. 
('71 Code, § 14-19; Ord. 227, passed 8-23-72) 
95.28 - Failure to obey notice; hearing and abatement. 
(A)  If, after the expiration date specified in the notice for the removal of the junk, the junk remains on the property, road right-of-way, or the waters of the town, the town manager shall forthwith report the fact to the town commission. The town commission shall cause notice of public hearing to be held before the town commission for the purpose of determining that the violation complained of does or does not, in fact, exist; and if, in fact, it does exist, why the violation should not be remedied by the owner, or if the owner fails to remedy the same, why it should not be remedied by the town at the expense of the owner. The town commission shall cause notice to the owner to be given as provided in section 95.27. 
(B)  The hearing shall be held as soon as possible, and the person to whom the notices are directed shall be advised of the time and place of the hearing at least 15 days in advance thereof. If, at the hearing, the town commission determines that no violation of this subchapter exists, then the matter shall be terminated at that time. If the commission finds that a violation does exist, it shall give the owner thereof reasonable time to remedy the violation, not to exceed 30 days from the date of the hearing. If the owner fails to remedy the violation, then and in such event the town manager shall forthwith cause the violation to be remedied by the town at the expense of the owner of the real property where the junk is located. 
('71 Code, § 14-20; Ord. 227, passed 8-23-72) 
95.29 - Removal by town; proposed assessment hearing. 
(A)  On the completion of the work, the town manager shall determine the costs of removing, carrying away, and disposing of the junk and shall cause a preliminary assessment roll to be made up containing a complete list of the property, road right-of-way, or the waters of the town cleared of junk under the provisions of this subchapter, together with the name of the owner as it appears from the town tax records. The records shall be known as the "preliminary assessment roll for junk clearing", and it shall be submitted to the town commission immediately upon completion. Thereupon, the town commission shall fix a date for a public hearing on the assessments appearing in the preliminary assessment roll. 
(B)  Immediately on the determination by the town commission of a date for public hearing on the proposed assessments referred to in subsection (A) above, the town manager shall give notice of the hearing, setting out the date thereof, the properties affected, the amount of the proposed assessments, and the name of the owners thereof or persons to whom the properties were last assessed as they appear in the preliminary assessment roll. The notice shall be given in the manner set out in section 95.28. The notice shall be mailed, delivered, or published not less than ten days before the date of the public hearing. 
('71 Code, §§ 14-21, 14-22; Ord. 227, passed 8-23-72) 
95.30 - Assessment to become property lien. 
(A)  The town commission shall, pursuant to the notice so published, meet at the time and place specified in the notice and proceed to hear any and all complaints from any person affected by any proposed assessment and shall proceed to correct any and all mistakes or errors then and there appearing on the preliminary assessment roll. On the approval by the town commission of the preliminary assessment roll as submitted, or as corrected, it shall be final. The amounts so then and there determined, assessed against the respective properties, shall from the date of the approval be and constitute a lien against the properties of equal dignity with the town and county taxes; however, the taxes shall not take priority over a recorded lien, mechanic's lien, or statutory lien existing on the effective date of this subchapter, and shall remain a lien against the respective properties until paid. 
(B)  The assessment roll, as finally approved, shall immediately be set out by the town clerk. It shall be a public record and the entry therein of any assessments shall be and constitute a notice to the public of the lien against the land so assessed. No other record of notice thereof shall be necessary to any person or corporation for that purpose. No error, omission, or mistake in regard to the name of the owner of any property shall be held to invalidate any assessment against the property. 
('71 Code, § 14-23) (Ord. 227, passed 8-23-72) 
95.31 - Interest on assessment lien. 
    The principal amount of all assessment liens levied and assessed under this subchapter shall bear interest at the rate of ten percent per year, commencing 30 days after final approval of the assessment roll by the town commission. The interest shall also constitute a lien against the property assessed, of equal dignity with the lien for the principal amount due. Any lien may be paid in full at any time after it is finally assessed, and interest shall be charged only to the date of payment. 
('71 Code, § 14-24; Ord. 227, passed 8-23-72) 
95.32 - Delinquent assessment lien. 
(A)  All special assessment liens and accrued interest levied and assessed under the provisions of this subchapter shall be deemed to be delinquent and past due as of the first day of April first occurring 60 days or more after the final assessment and levy of the liens by the town commission. If the liens shall not have been paid by that date, the same may be enforced in the manner herein provided. 
(B)  The liens created by this subchapter, when delinquent, shall be enforced and collected in the same manner and by the same methods provided for the enforcement and collection of delinquent ad valorem taxes for the town, and may be enforced and collected in an independent suit or in any suit or proceeding brought for the purpose of enforcing and collecting any such ad valorem taxes. In the alternative, the same may be enforced and collected in the same manner as provided by state law for the enforcement and collection of mechanic's liens. 
('71 Code, §§ 14-25, 14-26) 
95.33 - Right to appeal lien. 
    For the period of 30 days after the date on which liens entered into the assessment roll have been finally assessed and levied under this subchapter, any person aggrieved shall have the right to contest the legality thereof by suit, action, writ, or special proceeding, after which time, no suit, action, writ, or special proceeding in any manner questioning the legality of the lien shall lie for any cause whatsoever. 
('71 Code, § 14-27; Ord. 227, passed 8-23-72) 
95.34 - Statute of limitations. 
    The statute of limitations against the enforcement of liens assessed under the authority of this subchapter is 20 years from the date of final assessment and levy thereof. The town clerk is directed to note the date of final assessment in the assessment roll where the liens are set out, but his failure to do so shall not affect the validity or priority of the lien. 
('71 Code, § 14-28; Ord. 227, passed 8-23-72) 
Recycling 

95.41 - Mandatory recycling definitions. 
    As used in this subchapter, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    "Approved collector." Persons approved by the department to collect recyclable materials or yard trash. 
    "Biohazardous waste." Waste as defined by F.S. § 403.703(39), as may be amended. 
    "Biological waste." Waste as defined by F.S. § 403.703(41), as may be amended. 
    "Commercial user." Any person, including, but not limited to, owners, lessees, and sublessees utilizing a property for the exchange of goods, commodities or services, including, but not limited to, hotels, motels, recreational vehicle parks, marinas, offices, governmental, churches, and not-for-profit corporations. 
    "Commission." Town Commission of Longboat Key, Florida. 
    "Composting." The controlled biological decomposition of organic solid waste carried out under controlled conditions which stabilizes the organic fraction of waste into a material which can easily and safely be stored, handled and used in an environmentally acceptable manner for soil, growing medium, or other similar uses. Simple exposure of solid waste under uncontrolled adversely affecting the environment or public are not composting, composting activities shall not violate the provisions of other state or local laws, ordinances, rules, regulations, or orders. 
    "Construction and demolition debris." Demolition debris as defined in F.S. § 403.703(17), as may be amended. 
    "Curb." The border of a way, either private or public. 
    "Department." The Longboat Key Public Works Department, or any other department as may be designated by the town manager to administer and enforce this subchapter. 
    "Director." The director of the department. 
    "Hazardous waste." A hazardous waste as identified by the State of Florida Department of Environmental Regulation in Florida Administrative Code 17-730, as may be amended, or the United States Environmental Protection Agency pursuant to the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, 42 U.S.C. § 6901 et seq., and implementing regulations, as may be amended. 
    "Nonrecyclable solid waste." Solid waste which is not a recyclable material. 
    "Person." Any and all persons, natural or artificial, including any individual, firm or association; any municipal or private corporation organized or existing under the laws of this state or any other state as defined in F.S. § 403.703(4), as may be amended. 
    "Recyclable materials." Those materials which are capable of being recycled and which would otherwise be processed or disposed of as solid waste and includes the following list of materials, as defined, and which may be amended to add or delete materials by the commission at any time: 
(1)  "Aluminum cans." Any beverage container constructed entirely of aluminum. 
(2)  "Glass." Any food or beverage container constructed of glass of any color. 
(3)  "Newspaper." Dry newsprint including advertising inserts delivered in the newspaper, but excluding aged, yellowed or sunburned paper. 
(4)  "Recyclable construction and demolition debris." Construction and demolition debris from commercial users which is capable of being recycled, including wood pallets, wood construction materials, land-clearing debris such as branches, trees, scrap metal and concrete, brick, or asphalt which can be effectively processed for recycling; 
(5)  "Recyclable plastics." The following plastic bottles (as coded and labeled on the item by number placed inside a triangle and letters placed below the triangle pursuant to F.S. § 403.708(9)), as may be amended from time to time: 
(a)  High density polyethylene (coded and labeled HDPE, 2) bottles; 
(b)  Polyethlene terephthalate (coded and labeled PET, 1) bottles. 
(6)  "Steel cans." Food or beverage containers which consist primarily of ferrous metals, commonly called tin cans. 
    "Recycling." Any process, including composting, by which solid waste, or materials which would otherwise become solid waste, are collected, separated, processed and reused or returned to use in the form of raw materials or products. 
    "Recycling container." Any container authorized and approved by resolution of the commission for the collection of recyclable materials. 
    "Residential user." A person, including, but not limited to, owners, lessees, and sublessees utilizing a building, a portion thereof, specifically designed for and used for occupancy of that person. 
    "Solid waste." Solid waste as defined in F.S. § 403.703(13), as may be amended. 
    "Special waste." Solid wastes that can require special handling and management, including but not limited to, incinerator ash, biohazardous waste, biological waste, lead-acid batteries, whole tires, used oil and white goods. 
    "Town residential contract recycling collector." That person(s) with whom the town has contracted to provided collection of recyclable materials or yard trash for residential users. 
    "White goods." Inoperative or discarded refrigerators, ranges, washers, water heaters, freezers or other domestic or commercial large appliances. 
    "Whole tires." Whole tires as defined by the State of Florida Department of Environmental Regulation in Florida Administrative Code 17-711, as may be amended. 
    "Yard trash." Vegetative matter resulting from landscaping maintenance or land clearing, including, but not limited to, seaweed, shrub trimmings, tree trimmings, grass clippings and palm fronds. 
(Ord. 91-15, passed 9-5-91) 
95.42 - Mandatory recycling. 
(A)  Residential users. All residential users shall handle recyclable materials for recycling as follows: 
(1)  Residential users approved by the department for solid waste "can service" shall place recyclable materials at the curb in a location and container authorized by the town for collection. 
(2)  Residential users (multifamily) authorized for solid waste bulk collection shall place recyclable materials in containers authorized for collection. 
(3)  Mobile home parks shall use centralized containers or curbside collection as authorized by the department. 
(4)  Yard trash shall be separated and handled pursuant to section 95.44 of this subchapter. 
(5)  Residential users may deliver recyclable construction and demolition debris through independent delivery to a facility or facilities for recycling through an agreement with persons approved by the Town of Longboat Key Public Works Department. Alternatively, residential users may utilize the town's contractual arrangements, if available, for the collection of recyclable construction and demolition debris that services that area of the town. 
(6)  Rates for collections for residential users delivering recyclable construction and demolition debris through independent delivery may be approved by the town commission by resolution. 
(7)  A residential user delivering recyclable construction and demolition debris through independent delivery shall, upon request, furnish the town proof that it is recycling materials as defined above. 
(8)  All persons delivering recyclable construction and demolition debris to a facility or facilities for recycling shall obtain and maintain, at their sole cost and expense, not less than the insurance coverage required of the town's recycling collection services contractor. 
(B)  Commercial users. 
(1)  All commercial users shall recycle the recyclable materials as defined above and yard trash pursuant to section 95.44; however, commercial users may deliver recyclable materials or yard trash through independent delivery to a facility or facilities for recycling through an agreement with persons approved by the Town of Longboat Key Public Works Department. Alternatively, commercial users may utilize the town contractual arrangements, if available, for the collection of recyclable materials that service that area of town. 
(2)  Rates for collections for commercial users may be approved by the town commission by resolution. 
(3)  Commercial users shall comply with the requirements of this subchapter, including separation of recyclable materials and yard trash as described therein. 
(4)  A commercial user shall, upon request, furnish the town proof that it is recycling materials as defined above. 
(5)  All persons delivering recyclable materials to a facility or facilities for recycling shall obtain and maintain, at their sole cost and expense, not less than the insurance coverage required of the town's recycling collection services contractor. 
(Ord. 91-15, passed 9-5-91; Amd. Ord. 98-03, passed 3-2-98) 
95.43 - Combining recyclable materials, yard trash and solid waste prohibited. 
(A)  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the contrary, it shall be unlawful and a violation of this subchapter for any person to combine recyclable materials or yard trash with nonrecyclable solid waste in any combination or amount other than that approved by the town or to dispose of recyclable materials or yard trash in any manner other than recycling or composting. 
(B)  Any collector who unknowingly collects or transports recyclable materials or yard trash with nonrecyclable solid waste for disposal shall not be in violation of this subchapter. 
(C)  If the town has approved the collection of unseparated solid waste containing recyclable materials for transport to a processing facility for recycling, it shall not be a violation of this subchapter to combine recyclable materials or yard trash with nonrecyclable solid waste. 
(Ord. 91-15, passed 9-5-91) 
95.44 - Recycling of yard trash. 
    All residential or commercial users shall handle yard trash by one of the following methods: 
(A)  Yard trash may be delivered to a location to receive and collect yard trash for recycling. 
(B)  Yard trash may be disposed of by mulching and composting, provided that such mulching and composting shall be confined to the user's property and properly screened from neighboring property. 
(C)  Canned, bagged, or bundled yard trash may be placed at the curb or other location authorized for collection of yard trash for delivery to a recycling facility. 
(Ord. 91-15, passed 9-5-91) 
95.45 - Hazardous and special wastes. 
(A)  No person shall place the following materials or items for collection and disposal in a municipal solid waste landfill or municipal solid waste incinerator: Hazardous waste, incinerator ash (excluding ash from human and animal cremation), biohazardous or biological waste, lead-acid batteries, whole tires, used oil, yard trash, white goods. 
    These hazardous and special wastes shall be recycled, except incinerator ash, or placed in special management areas for storage, collection, or disposal in accordance with applicable federal, state and local permits and requirements. 
(B)  Residential users may dispose of household wastes with hazardous components at times and locations designated by the county pursuant to the Sarasota County Household Hazardous Waste or Manatee County Collection Day Program ("amnesty days") or pursuant to disposal methods authorized or recommended by the department in rules, regulations or educational programs for the safe disposal of household wastes with hazardous components. Household wastes with hazardous components shall be stored out of reach of small children until disposed of safely. 
(C)  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the contrary, it shall be unlawful and a violation of this subchapter for any residential or commercial user to combine hazardous waste with any recyclable materials, yard trash, or any other solid waste for collection or disposal. 
(D)  Commercial users shall contract with the "amnesty days" contractor or other licensed and permitted hazardous waste transportation and treatment, storage or disposal facility for disposal or recycling of hazardous waste. 
(Ord. 91-15, passed 9-5-91) 
95.46 - Ownership of containers. 
    Containers for residential recycling which may be provided to users shall be and remain the sole property of the town or collection contractor. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this subchapter for any person to use such containers for any other purpose than storing recyclable materials for collection, to intentionally damage or destroy such containers, or to fail to return such containers to Longboat Key or the collection contractor when no longer used for such purposes. 
(Ord. 91-15, passed 9-5-91) 
95.47 - Ownership of recyclable materials. 
    Prior to the time of placement of recyclable materials at the curb or location specified for collection, this subchapter shall not limit the right of, or prohibit, any person from donating, selling, or otherwise lawfully recycling recyclable materials. The person delivering the recycling material shall state Longboat Key as the source of the material; and the amount of recyclable materials donated, sold or recycled shall be reported to the department by any person accepting or collecting recyclable materials. From the time of placement of residential recyclable materials at the curb, or other authorized, centralized location specified for collection, such recyclable materials shall become and be the sole property of Longboat Key or its authorized agent. 
(Ord. 91-15, passed 9-5-91) 
95.48 - Unauthorized removal of recyclable materials. 
    It shall be unlawful and a violation of this subchapter for any person, without approval from the department, to collect, pick up, remove, or cause to be collected, picked up, or removed, any recyclable material from the curb or authorized, centralized location. The collection, pickup, or removal of each recyclable item shall constitute a separate offense and violation of this subchapter. 
(Ord. 91-15, passed 9-5-91) 
95.49 - Fees for removal of recyclable materials. 
    A franchisee is hereby authorized to charge for the removal of recyclable materials for which the property owner is responsible. 
(Ord. 91-15, passed 9-5-91) 
95.50 - Billing of recyclable collection service charges to customers. 
    All payments for removal of recyclable materials shall be on a current basis. Bills for regularly scheduled collections will be rendered by the town, or the town's franchisee. 
(Ord. 91-15, passed 9-5-91; Amd. Ord. 03-13, passed 7-7-03) 
95.51 - Rules and regulation relating to separation and curbside collection and collection fees of recyclable materials. 
(A)  The commission may establish and adopt by resolution, after a public hearing, rules and regulations as shall be necessary to implement the provisions of this subchapter, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Cost-effective separation and collection of recyclable materials and yard trash in Longboat Key; 
(2)  The frequency and location of collection of recyclable materials and yard trash; 
(3)  The type of containers for recyclable materials; 
(4)  Approval of collectors of recyclable materials and yard trash; 
(5)  Additions or deletions to the lists of recyclable materials at any time; 
(6)  Additions or deletions to the lists of wastes with hazardous components which are not suitable for landfills or digestion composting; or 
(7)  Collection fees. 
(B)  The establishment of a franchise agreement and its amendments thereto shall also be deemed to establish rules and regulations under this subchapter. 
(C)  Any violation of the rules and regulations established under this subchapter shall be deemed a violation of this subchapter and shall be enforced in the same manner. 
(Ord. 91-15, passed 9-5-91; Amd. Ord. 03-13, passed 7-7-03) 
95.52 - Promotion of recycling. 
    Programs shall be implemented for the purpose of educating the citizens of Longboat Key concerning mandatory recycling requirements, promoting recycling among the citizens, reducing the amount of hazardous waste generated by households and commercial uses, and proper collection and handling of recyclable materials, yard trash, household waste with hazardous components and nonrecyclable solid waste. Appropriations and expenditures for educational and promotional purposes pursuant to this section is declared to be for lawful public purposes. 
(Ord. 91-15, passed 9-5-91) 
95.53 - Procurement of recycled product. 
    The town shall purchase products or materials with recycled content when they are available within ten percent of the price of the lowest bidder and within a reasonable period of time and meet the performance standards of applicable specifications or standards of the town. 
(Ord. 91-15, passed 9-5-91) 
95.54 - Penalties and enforcement. 
(A)  Inspection. Inspectors of the department and sworn police officers of the town are authorized to inspect any container, bag or can and any collection, processing, recycling, composting, transporting or disposal facility at any time for compliance with this subchapter. 
(B)  Enforcement. Inspectors of the department or any sworn police officers of the town are authorized and directed to strictly enforce this subchapter pursuant to F.S. § 162.21. Copies of this subchapter, and any amendments or resolutions adopted pursuant to this subchapter, shall be distributed to each inspector and police officer. Inspectors and police officers shall become familiar with this subchapter and shall cite all violators according to the penalty provisions of this subchapter. 
    An inspector or police officer shall issue a citation to a person when, based upon personal investigation, the inspector or police officer has reasonable cause to believe that the person has committed a civil infraction in violation of this subchapter. For a first offense and prior to issuing a citation, an inspector or police officer shall provide notice to the person that the person has committed a violation of a code or ordinance and shall establish a time period of seven days within which the person must correct the violation. If, upon personal investigation, an inspector or police officer finds that the person has not corrected the violation within seven days, an inspector or police officer shall issue a citation to the person who has committed the violation indicating the dollar amount of the civil penalty and notice of the right to contest the citation in county court within 30 days pursuant to F.S. § 162.21. 
(1)  If the person elects not to contest the citation, the person shall pay the applicable civil penalty to the clerk of the circuit court within 30 days after issuance of the citation. 
(2)  If the person elects to contest the citation, the person shall request a hearing through the clerk of the circuit court within 30 days after the issuance of the citation. The clerk shall schedule a hearing in the county court and shall provide written notice of the hearing to the person and the inspector or police officer. Citations contested in the county court shall be subject to court costs and a civil penalty not to exceed $500.00. 
(3)  If the person fails to pay the civil penalty within the time allowed, or fails to appear in court to contest the citation, the person shall be deemed to have waived his right to contest the citation; and, in such case, judgment may be entered against the person for an amount up to $500.00. 
(4)  Any person who willfully refuses to sign and accept a citation issued by an inspector or police officer shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the second degree, punishable as provided by F.S. §§ 775.082, 775.083, or § 775.084. 
(C)  Penalties. A violation of the provisions of this subchapter, other than sections 95.45 and 95.48, by any person shall be punishable by civil penalties in a dollar amount as set forth in the attached schedule for a first offense and second or third offenses within one year of the first. Violations of section 95.45 (Hazardous and Special Wastes) or section 95.48 (Unauthorized Removal of Recyclable Materials) by any person shall be prosecuted in the same manner as a misdemeanor, and punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00 or by imprisonment in the county jail not to exceed 60 days or by both fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. 91-15, passed 9-5-91) 
95.55 - Conflict with other laws. 
    In the event of a direct conflict between the provisions of this subchapter and F.S. ch. 403, or implementing regulations, the provisions of F.S. ch. 403, or implementing regulations, shall prevail if stricter or more stringent than this subchapter. In the event of a conflict between the provisions of this subchapter and a federal statute or regulation, the federal statute or regulation shall prevail. 
(Ord. 91-15, passed 9-5-91)
