(1)  Minor grading and the placement of minor quantities of nonstructural fill shall be permitted for landscaping and for drainage purposes under and around buildings. 
(2)  Nonstructural fill with finished slopes that are steeper than one unit vertical to five units horizontal shall be permitted only if an analysis prepared by a qualified registered design professional demonstrates no harmful diversion of floodwaters or wave run-up and wave reflection that would increase damage to adjacent buildings and structures. 
(3)  Where authorized by the Florida Department of Environmental Protection or applicable local approval, sand dune construction and restoration of sand dunes under or around elevated buildings are permitted without additional engineering analysis or certification of the diversion of floodwater or wave run-up and wave reflection if the scale and location of the dune work is consistent with local beach-dune morphology and the vertical clearance is maintained between the top of the sand dune and the lowest horizontal structural member of the building. 
(Ord. 2013-25, passed 1-6-14) 
154.308 - Local administrative amendments to the Florida Building Code. 
(A)  The Florida Building Code. Sections 104.10.1, 107.6.1 and 117 are hereby amended by the following administrative amendments to the Florida Building Code, Building: 
(1)  Add a new Section 104.10.1 as follows: 
 104.10.1 Modifications of the strict application of the requirements of the Florida Building Code. The Building Official shall coordinate with the Floodplain Administrator to review requests submitted to the Building Official that seek approval to modify the strict application of the flood-resistant construction requirements of the Florida Building Code to determine whether such requests require the granting of a variance pursuant to § 117. 
(2)  Add a new Section 107.6.1 as follows: 
 107.6.1 Building permits issued on the basis of an affidavit. Pursuant to the requirements of federal regulation for participation in the National Flood Insurance Program (44 C.F.R. §§ 59 and 60), the authority granted to the Building Official to issue permits, to rely on inspections, and to accept plans and construction documents on the basis of affidavits and plans submitted pursuant to Sections 105.14 and 107.6, shall not extend to the flood load and flood-resistant construction requirements of the Florida Building Code. 
(3)  Add a new Section 117 as follows: 
 117 Variances in Flood Hazard Areas 
 117.1 Flood hazard areas. Pursuant to F.S. § 553.73(5), the variance procedures adopted in the local floodplain management ordinance shall apply to requests submitted to the Building Official for variances to the provisions of Section 1612.4 of the Florida Building Code, Building or, as applicable, the provisions of Section R322 of the Florida Building Code, Residential. This section shall not apply to Section 3109 of the Florida Building Code, Building. 
(B)  The Florida Building Code, Residential is hereby amended by the following technical amendments: 
(1)  Add new Section R322.2.1 and renumber, as follows: 
 R322.2.1 Elevation requirements. 
1.  Buildings and structures in flood hazard areas not designated as Coastal A Zones shall have the lowest floors elevated to or above the base flood elevation plus 1 foot or the design flood elevation, whichever is higher. 
2.  Buildings and structures in flood hazard areas designated as Coastal A Zones shall have the lowest floors elevated to or above the base flood elevation plus 1 foot (305 mm), or to the design flood elevation, whichever is higher. 
3.  Buildings and structures seaward of the coastal construction control line shall have the lowest horizontal structural member of the lowest floors elevated to or above the base flood elevation plus 3 feet. 
4.  In areas of shallow flooding (AO Zones), buildings and structures shall have the lowest floor (including basement) elevated at least as high above the highest adjacent grade as the depth number specified in feet on the FIRM, or at least 2 feet (610 mm) if a depth number is not specified. 
5.  Basement floors that are below grade on all sides shall be elevated to or above the design flood elevation. 
 Exception: Enclosed areas below the design flood elevation, including basements whose floors are not below grade on all sides, shall meet the requirements of Section R322.2.2. 
(2)  Modify Section R322.3.2 as follows: 
 R322.3.2 Elevation requirements. 
1.  All buildings and structures erected within coastal high hazard areas shall be elevated so that the lowest portion of all structural members supporting the lowest floor, with the exception of mat or raft foundations, piling, pile caps, columns, grade beams and bracing, is at or above the base flood elevation plus 3 feet or the design flood elevation, whichever is higher. 
2.  Basement floors that are below grade on all sides are prohibited. 
3.  The use of fill for structural support is prohibited. 
4.  Minor grading, and the placement of minor quantities of fill, shall be permitted for landscaping and for drainage purposes under and around buildings and for support of parking slabs, pool decks, patios and walkways. 
 Exception: Walls and partitions enclosing areas below the design flood elevation shall meet the requirements of Sections R322.3.4 and R322.3.5. 
(C)  The Florida Building Code, Building is hereby amended by the following technical amendments: 
(1)  Modify a definition in Section 1612.2 as follows: 
 "SUBSTANTIAL DAMAGE." Damage of any origin sustained by a structure whereby the cost of restoring the structure to its before-damaged condition would equal or exceed 50 percent of the market value of the structure before the damage occurred. The term also includes flood-related damage sustained by a structure on two separate occasions during a 10-year period for which the cost of repairs at the time of each such flood event, on average, equals or exceeds 25 percent of the market value of the structure before the damage occurred. 
(2)  Add a new Sec. 1612.4.1 as follows: 
 1612.4.1 Elevation requirements. The minimum elevation requirements in flood hazard areas subject to high velocity wave action (coastal high hazard areas) and in areas seaward of the coastal construction control line shall be as specified in ASCE 24 or the base flood elevation plus 3 feet, whichever is higher. 
(D)  The Florida Building Code, Existing Building is hereby amended by the following technical amendment: 
(1)  Modify a definition in Section 202 as follows: 
 "SUBSTANTIAL DAMAGE." Damage of any origin sustained by a structure whereby the cost of restoring the structure to its before-damaged condition would equal or exceed 50 percent of the market value of the structure before the damage occurred. The term also includes flood-related damage sustained by a structure on two separate occasions during a 10-year period for which the cost of repairs at the time of each such flood event, on average, equals or exceeds 25 percent of the market value of the structure before the damage occurred. 
(Ord. 2013-25, passed 1-6-14) 
Note- Section 8 of Ord. 2013-25 states an effective date for these provisions as March 17, 2014.

Chapter 156 - SIGN CODE[5] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. 2017-03, § 2(Exh. A), passed July 9, 2018, amended ch. 156 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former ch. 156, §§ 156.01-156.100, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from: 1971 Code §§ 18-1-18-14; Ord. 73-12, passed 5-24-73; Ord. 78-12, passed 10-25-78; Ord. 79-14, passed 8-1-79; Ord. 84-13, passed 12-3-84; Ord. 88-29, passed 11-7-88; Ord. 90-06, passed 3-19-90; Ord. 92-17, passed 6-18-92; Ord. 93-25, passed 2-7-94; Ord. 94-01, passed 3-24-94; Ord. 96-03, passed 5-6-94; Ord. 95-04, passed 5-1-95; Ord. 96-08, passed 6-3-96; Ord. 97-08, passed 7-7-97; Ord. 2000-10, passed 7-10-00; Ord. 02-12, passed 11-4-02; and Ord. No. 2010-20, § 2, passed Nov. 18, 2010. 
Cross reference- Zoning use regulations, § 158.037. 

156.01 - Findings, purpose and intent; interpretation. 
(A)  Signs obstruct views, distract motorists, displace alternative uses for land, and pose other problems that legitimately call for regulation. The purpose of this chapter is to regulate the size, color, illumination, movement, materials, location, height, and condition of all signs placed on private property for exterior observation, thus ensuring the protection of property values, the character of the various neighborhoods, the creation of a convenient, attractive, and harmonious community, and economic development. This article allows adequate communication through signage while encouraging aesthetic quality in the design, location, size, and purpose of all signs. This article shall be interpreted in a manner consistent with the First Amendment guarantee of free speech. If any provision of this chapter is found by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid, such finding shall not affect the validity of other provisions of this article which can be given effect without the invalid provision. 
(B)  Any person seeking to display a permanent sign regulated by this chapter is required to apply for and obtain a sign permit prior to lawful placement of the sign structure and sign. Any sign that is not authorized or exempt from the requirements of this chapter is prohibited. 
(C)  A sign placed on land or on a building for the purpose of identification, protection, or directing persons to a use conducted therein shall be deemed to be an integral but accessory and subordinate part of the principal use of land or building. Therefore, the intent of this chapter is to establish limitations on signs in order to ensure they are appropriate to the land, building, or use to which they are appurtenant and are adequate for their intended purpose while balancing the individual and community interests identified in subsection (A) of this section. 
(D)  These regulations are intended to promote signs that are compatible with the use of the property to which they are appurtenant, landscape, and architecture of surrounding buildings, are legible and appropriate to the activity to which they pertain, are not distracting to motorists, and are constructed and maintained in a structurally sound and attractive condition. 
(E)  These regulations do not regulate every form and instance of visual communication that may be displayed anywhere within the jurisdictional limits of the town. Rather, they are intended to regulate those forms and instances that are most likely to meaningfully affect one or more of the purposes set forth above. 
(F)  These regulations do not entirely eliminate all of the harms that may be created by the installation and display of signs. Rather, they strike an appropriate balance that preserves ample channels of communication by means of visual display while still reducing and mitigating the extent of the harms caused by signs. 
(G)  These regulations are not intended to and do not apply to signs erected, maintained or otherwise posted, owned or leased by the state, the federal government or the town. The inclusion of "government" in describing some signs does not intend to subject the government to regulation, but instead helps explain the type of sign that falls within the immunities of the government from regulation. 
(Ord. 2017-03, passed 7-9-18) 
156.02 - Definitions. 
    Above-roof sign. A sign displayed above the peak or parapet of a building. 
    Animation or animated. The movement or the optical illusion of movement of any part of the sign structure, design, or pictorial segment, including the movement of any illumination or the flashing or varying of light intensity; the automatic changing of all or any part of the facing of a sign. 
    Art display. A hand-painted work of visual art or a mechanically produced or computer generated print or image that is either affixed to or painted directly on the exterior wall of a structure with the permission of the property owner. 
    Awning. A cloth, plastic, or other nonstructural covering that is permanently attached to a building or other structure, or that can be raised or retracted to a position against the building or other structure when not in use. 
    Banner. A sign on a lightweight material either enclosed or not enclosed in a rigid frame and secured or mounted to allow motion caused by the atmosphere. 
    Canopy. A structure other than an awning made of cloth, metal, or other material with frames affixed to a building and carried by a frame that is supported by the ground. 
    Changeable copy. Copy that changes at intervals of more than once every 20 minutes. 
    Code. Unless otherwise specifically referenced means the Code of the Town of Longboat Key. 
    Commercial center. A commercial development under unified control consisting of more than two separate commercial establishments that share common parking entranceways. 
    Digital billboard. A sign that is static and changes messages by any electronic process or remote control. 
    Flag. A piece of cloth or similar material, typically oblong or square, attachable by one edge to a pole or rope. 
    Flat wall (facade-mounted) sign. A sign affixed directly to or inscribed on an exterior wall and confined within the limits thereof of any building and which projects from that surface less than 12 inches at all points. 
    Freestanding sign. A sign erected and maintained on a freestanding frame, mast, or pole not attached to any building, and not including ground-mounted signs. 
    Government sign. A government sign is a sign that is constructed, placed, or maintained by the federal, state, or local government or a sign that is required to be constructed, placed, or maintained by the federal, state, or local government either directly or to enforce a property owner's rights. 
    Ground-mounted sign. A sign which extends from the ground, or has support which places the bottom of the sign no more than two feet from the ground. 
    Historical sign. A sign officially designated as historical by the Town Commission of Longboat Key, Florida. 
    Lessee. A person who rents property. 
    Marquee sign. A canopy or covering structure bearing a signboard or copy projecting from and attached to a building. 
    Nonconforming sign. A sign that was lawfully constructed or installed prior to the adoption or amendment of this chapter and was in compliance with all of the provisions of this chapter then in effect, but that does not presently comply with this chapter. 
    Outdoor advertising sign. A sign that advertises goods, products, or services which are not sold, manufactured, or distributed on or from the premises or facilities on which the sign is located. 
    Portable sign. Any structure without a permanent foundation or otherwise permanently attached to a fixed location, which can be carried, towed, hauled, or driven and is primarily designed to be moved rather than be limited to a fixed location regardless of modifications that limit its movability. 
    Projecting sign. A sign, other than a wall sign, which projects from and is supported by a wall of a building or structure. 
    Roof sign. A sign located on or above the roof of any building, not including false mansard roof, canopy, or other fascia. 
    Sign. A name, identification, description, display, or illustration, which is affixed to, painted, or represented directly or indirectly upon a building, or other outdoor surface which directs attention to or is designed or intended to direct attention to the sign face or to an object, product, place, activity, person, institution, organization, or business. Signs located completely within an enclosed building or not exposed to view from a public beach, public beach and bay accesses, public waterway, or street shall not be considered a sign. Each display surface of a sign or sign face shall be considered to be a sign. 
    Sign area. The space enclosed within the extreme edges of the sign for each sign face, not including the supporting structure or where attached directly to a building wall or surface, the space within the outline enclosing all the characters of the words, numbers, or design. 
    Sign face. The entire display surface area of a sign upon, against, or through which copy is placed. 
    Sign structure. Any structure which is designed specifically for the purpose of supporting a sign or is capable of supporting a sign, including decorative covers, braces, wires, and supports or components attached to or placed around the sign structure. 
    Snipe sign. Any small sign, generally of a temporary nature, made of any material, when such sign is tacked, nailed, posted, pasted, glued, or otherwise attached to trees, poles, stakes, fences, or other objects not erected, owned, and maintained by the owner of the sign. 
    Temporary sign. A banner, pennant, poster, or advertising display constructed of paper, cloth, canvas, plastic sheet, cardboard, wallboard, plywood, or other like materials and that appears to be intended or is determined by the code official to be displayed for a limited period of time. 
    Vehicle sign. Any sign attached to or displayed on a vehicle or trailer, which is parked or placed in position for display to the public. 
    Window sign. A sign applied, painted, or affixed on a window of a building or mounted within 12 inches of a window and visible to the outside. 
(Ord. 2017-03, passed 7-9-18) 
156.03 - Prohibited signs. 
(A)  Signs are prohibited in all districts unless: 
(1)  Constructed pursuant to a valid building permit when required under this Code; and 
(2)  Authorized under this Code. 
(B)  A property owner may not accept a fee for posting or maintaining a temporary sign allowed under subsection 156.04(C) and any sign that is posted or maintained in violation of this provision is prohibited. 
(C)  Notwithstanding subsection (A) above, the following signs are specifically prohibited: 
(1)  Any sign of a size, location, movement, coloring, or manner of illumination which may be confused with or construed as a traffic control device or which hide from view any traffic or street sign or signal; 
(2)  Any sign containing or consisting of banners, balloons, posters, pennants, ribbons, streamers, strings of light bulbs, spinners, or other similarly moving devices or signs which may move or swing as a result of wind pressure; 
(3)  Any sign having blinking, flashing, or fluttering lights or other illuminating devices which exhibit movement; 
(4)  Art displays; 
(5)  Digital billboards; 
(6)  Outdoor advertising signs; 
(7)  Snipe signs; 
(8)  Permanent freestanding signs; 
(9)  Roof signs; 
(10)  Above-roof signs; 
(11)  Signs displaying an obscene or pornographic message; 
(12)  Signs emitting or projecting moving graphics, animations, audible sound, vapor, smoke, odor, gaseous matter, radio, television, or other electronic communication interference; 
(13)  Vehicle signs. 
(Ord. 2017-03, passed 7-9-18) 
156.04 - Authorized signs-Generally. 
(A)  Although these regulations do not apply to signs erected, maintained, or posted by the state, United States, or the town, these regulations clarify that Government signs which form the expression of that government are allowed in every zoning district and include the signs described and regulated below when erected and maintained pursuant to law. 
(1)  Each property owner must mark their property using numerals that identify the address of the property so that public safety departments can easily identify the address from the public street. 
(2)  Where a federal, state, or local law requires a property owner to post a sign on the owner's property to warn of a danger or to prohibit access to the property either generally or specifically, the owner shall comply with the federal, state, or local law to exercise that authority by posting a sign on the property. If the federal, state, or local regulation describes the form and dimensions of the sign, the property owner shall comply with those requirements, otherwise, when not defined, the sign shall be no larger than two square feet and located in a place on the property to provide access to the notice that is required to be made. Signs posted under this section are not snipe signs. 
(3)  Official notices or advertisements posted or displayed by or under the direction of any public or court officer in the performance of official or directed duties; provided, that all such signs shall be removed by the property owner no more than ten days after their purpose has been accomplished or as otherwise required by law. Signs posted under this section are not snipe signs. 
(B)  The signs described in subsection (A) are an important component of measures necessary to protect the public safety and serve the compelling governmental interest of protecting traffic safety, complying with legal requirements, serving the requirements of emergency response, and protecting property rights or the rights of persons on property. 
(C)  Temporary signs. 
(1)  A property owner may place one sign with a sign face no larger than one square foot on their property at any time for a period not to exceed six months. The top of the sign face and structure shall not exceed two feet above the ground. This section does not authorize snipe signs. 
(2)  One temporary sign no larger than three square feet supported by a white maximum four-inch by four-inch support post may be located on a property. A one square foot informational strip or rider may be attached to the sign. The top of the sign face and structure, including the supporting arm of the post and information strip or rider, shall not exceed four feet above the ground. This section does not authorize snipe signs. This sign may only be displayed while the property is being offered for sale, rent or lease through a licensed real estate agent or by owner with advertising in a local newspaper of general circulation or online until the earliest of two business days after transfer of ownership, when the property is no longer for rent, sale or lease, or when the lease or rent period commences. 
(3)  Location and standards. Temporary signs shall: 
(a)  Not be located within any public right-of-way whether dedicated or owned in fee simple or as an easement; 
(b)  Be placed by the property owner or with the property owner's consent and shall not be placed on any utility pole, street light, similar object, or on public property; 
(c)  Be located in the yard facing the street, driveway, or other vehicular access point and shall be no closer to a public street than a minimum of two feet inside the property line; 
(d)  Not be illuminated; 
(e)  Be removed within the applicable time period. 
(D)  For purposes of this chapter, the lessee of a property is considered the property owner as to the property the lessee holds a right to use exclusive of others (or the sole right to occupy). The terms of a lease or other agreement under which the property is occupied controls in determining whether property is occupied exclusively by a lessee. If there are multiple lessees of a property then each lessee shall have the same rights and duties as the property owner as to the property the lessee leases and has the sole right to occupy and the size of the property shall be deemed to be the property that the lessee has the sole right to occupy under the lease. 
(E)  Flags. One flag per premises is allowed. The flag pole must be no higher than the maximum height for the zoning district, as measured at ground level. Flag poles shall be no closer than ten feet from the premises property line. 
(Ord. 2017-03, passed 7-9-18) 
156.05 - Permit required. 
(A)  In general. A sign permit is required prior to the display and erection of any sign except exempt signs as described in section 156.06 and temporary signs as described in subsection 156.04(C). 
(B)  Application for permit. 
(1)  The real property owner or his authorized agent shall submit a sign permit application on forms furnished by the town, together with applicable fees, for all signs not specifically exempted. The applicant shall provide sufficient information to determine if the proposed sign is allowed under this code and other applicable laws, regulations, and ordinances. 
(2)  The town shall promptly process the sign permit application and approve the application, reject the application, or notify the applicant of deficiencies in the application. Any application that complies with all provisions of this code, the zoning ordinance, the building code, and other applicable laws, regulations, and ordinances shall be approved. 
(3)  No permit for any permanent sign shall be issued until a building permit has been issued for the building, structure, or establishment to which it relates. 
(4)  No sign permits shall be issued to an applicant that has an outstanding sign code violation, including but not limited to, full payment of fines, storage costs, and the correction of all violations. 
(C)  Permit fee. Fees for each category of sign shall be in the amounts determined by the town commission in a fee schedule. All fees shall be paid prior to the issuance of a permit or renewal. 
(D)  Duration and revocation of permit. If a sign is not installed within six months following the issuance of a sign permit, the permit shall be void. The town may revoke a sign permit under any of the following circumstances: 
(1)  The town determines that information in the application was materially false or misleading; 
(2)  The sign as installed does not conform to the sign permit application; 
(3)  The sign violates this sign code, building code, or other applicable law, regulation or ordinance; 
(4)  The town determines that the sign is not being properly maintained or has been abandoned. 
(Ord. 2017-03, passed 7-9-18) 
156.06 - Signs exempt. 
    The following signs are exempt from the regulations contained in this chapter: 
(A)  Government signs and signs required by law. 
(B)  Any sign integrated into or on an ATM, coin-operated machine, gasoline pump, telephone booth, vending machine, or similar equipment or machine. 
(C)  A sign carried by a person. 
(D)  Historical signs. 
(Ord. 2017-03, passed 7-9-18) 
156.07 - Specific sign regulations. 
(A)  Generally: 
(1)  Landscaping. All ground-mounted signs shall be placed in a landscaped setting appropriate to the size and scale of the sign. 
(2)  Design. Ground-mounted signs shall be constructed of the same materials, colors, and architectural style as buildings on the site. Ground-mounted signs shall be constructed of high quality materials and finishes. Acceptable materials include wood, masonry, metal, stone, glass, ceramic, and other similar materials. 
(3)  Intersection visibility triangle (see appendix A). In the intersection visibility triangle, no ground-mounted sign is permitted to exceed 30 inches in height above the established grade of the street property line, unless the sign is located in a median located within an intersecting right-of-way and setback a minimum of five feet from the street right-of-way. 
(4)  Illumination: 
(a)  Prohibited types. A sign shall not have exposed neon tube, animated, flashing, or changeable illumination. 
(b)  Requirements. All permanent signs are allowed to be non-illuminated or illuminated by internal or by external illumination. Signs that are externally illuminated shall be illuminated only with steady, stationary, and shielded light sources directed solely onto the sign. For signs that are internally illuminated, the illumination, with a designation of "cool white," "warm white," or "daylite" shall be emitted through no more than 25 percent of the sign face with the remainder of the sign face opaque. Notwithstanding other provisions within this chapter, all lighting shall comply with chapter 100, Sea Turtles. 
(c)  Brightness. No sign is allowed to be illuminated in a manner other than that which is necessary for clear and adequate visibility, and no sign is allowed of such intensity or brilliance as to impair the vision of a motor vehicle operator with average eyesight or to otherwise interfere with the driver's operation of a motor vehicle, and no sign is allowed to be of such intensity or brilliance that it interferes with the effectiveness of an official traffic sign, device, or signal. 
(d)  Malfunctions in illumination. Illumination elements shall be equipped with a means to discontinue the element immediately if it malfunctions. The owner of a sign with an illumination element shall immediately stop the element's operation when notified by the town that it is not complying with the standards of this sign code, except to bring the sign into conformance, or after conformance is confirmed by the town. 
(e)  Glare. Any lighting fixture on a sign that is located within ten feet of a property line of a residential zoning district or an existing residential use, or within ten feet of a public right-of-way, unless otherwise permitted by this chapter, shall be: 
(i)  Classified as an IES Type III or Type IV lighting fixture; and 
(ii)  Shielded on the side closest to the residential use, residential zoning district, or public right-of-way. 
(f)  Illuminated tubing. Neon and LED-style signs shall be no larger than two square feet in area. 
(B)  Residential districts: 
(1)  Scope: This subsection applies to permanent signs in all residential districts, MUC-3, and residential uses in MUC-1 and MUC-2. 
(2)  Size: 
(a)  For residential developments (including subdivision identification), the maximum size and number of ground-mounted signs that the owner or owners of the residential development may erect and maintain at the entrances to the development shall be controlled according to the following: 
(i)  Residential developments with 0-99 feet of linear street frontage may have a sign or signs with a maximum sign face and structure of no more than 16 square feet. 
(ii)  Residential developments with more than 99 feet of linear street frontage may have a sign or signs which have a maximum sign face and structure of no more than 42 square feet. 
(3)  Location: Permitted signs may be anywhere on the premises, except in a required side yard or within two feet of a street right-of-way. 
(4)  Height: 
(a)  For residential developments (including subdivision identification), the top of the sign and sign structure shall not exceed 12 feet above the ground. 
(5)  The following signs are not allowed: portable signs, marquee signs, digital billboard, outdoor advertising sign, and projecting sign. 
(C)  Commercial, tourism and institutional districts: 
(1)  Scope: This subsection applies to permanent signs in INS, OI, C-1, C-2, C-3, M-1, T-3, T-6 districts, and non-residential uses in MUC-1 and MUC-2. 
(2)  Number and size: 
(a)  For each lot or parcel one ground-mounted sign per street frontage shall be authorized: 
(b)  Ground-mounted signs shall not exceed the following area requirements based on the linear feet of street frontage per lot or parcel: 
Zoning District Linear Feet of Street Frontage Maximum Size of Sign Face and Structure Maximum Height of Sign and Sign Structure 1 Setbacks INS, MUC-1, MUC-2, OI, C-1, C-2, C-3, M-1, T-3 and T-6 0-99 feet 16 square feet 8 feet for single tenant property; 12 feet for multi-tenant property or a tourism development 2 feet INS, MUC-1, MUC-2, OI, C-1, C-2, C-3, M-1, T-3 and T-6 99+ feet 42 square feet 8 feet for single tenant property; 12 feet for multi-tenant property or a tourism development 2 feet  
1  Setback measured from each property line and street right-of-way. 
(c)  Two or more lots or parcels in a unified development shall combine their linear footage for the purpose of providing one common ground-mounted sign. The maximum height of the sign and sign structure shall not exceed 12 feet and the sign face and sign structure shall not exceed 42 square feet. 
(d)  Corner or through lots: Where a lot fronts on more than one street, only the square footage computed for each street frontage shall face that street frontage. 
(e)  Buildings may utilize flat wall signs, awning signs, and projecting signs. When combined, the total square footage of the sign face and structure may not exceed the following per parcel: 
Lineal Feet of Frontage Maximum Size of Sign Face
and Structure 0-99 Feet 16 Square Feet 99+ Feet 42 Square Feet  
(f)  Commercial center: In Commercial Centers notwithstanding subsection (e), individual businesses are also allowed a flat wall sign no greater than ten square feet. 
(3)  Location: 
(a)  Flat wall signs may be located on any wall of the building and shall not extend above the top of a parapet wall or a roofline at the wall, whichever is higher. 
(b)  Ground-mounted signs may be located anywhere on the premises except within an intersection visibility triangle or within a required setback per subsection (C)(2)(b). 
(c)  Projecting signs shall: 
(i)  Clear sidewalks by at least eight feet and project no more than two feet from a building or one-third the width of the sidewalk, whichever is less, but in no case impede pedestrian access, ingress, or egress or compromise ADA compliance. 
(ii)  Project from the wall or ceiling at an angle of 90 degrees. 
(d)  Awning signs shall clear sidewalks by at least eight feet and are not allowed to extend closer than one foot from the vertical plane formed by the curb or the right-of-way line. 
(4)  Window signs: Window signs in total shall not exceed 20 percent of the gross glass area of a business and: 
(a)  Shall not be placed on the exterior of a window. 
(b)  If illuminated are limited to two square feet maximum. 
(c)  Shall comply with any requirements of a law enforcement agency relative to the public safety of the occupants or a first responder. 
(d)  Shall comply with the restrictions or requirements of any applicable licensing agency of the business. 
(5)  Automated teller machines. Where automated teller machine (ATM) signs are allowed, signs may be placed on the ATM subject to the following requirements: 
(a)  The sign shall be an integral part of the ATM; 
(b)  May not exceed 2-1/2 square feet in total size, including any border or background color. 
(D)  Changeable copy signs. 
(1)  Changeable copy signs are permitted only as part of a permanent sign and shall be incorporated into the sign face, but not the sign structure. 
(2)  The signs can only be erected in nonresidential zoned property or property which is zoned residential but has a legal nonconforming use. 
(3)  The changeable copy area of the sign shall not exceed 25 percent of the sign face. 
(4)  The font and size of the changeable copy shall be uniform. 
(5)  The copy shall not be able to be changed electronically. 
(E)  Historical signs. 
(1)  Designation as a historical sign. An owner of a sign is allowed to petition the town commission for designation of a sign as historical and exempt from this chapter. In making its determination, the town commission shall consider whether: 
(a)  The sign is registered or certified by the Manatee County Historical Preservation Board or the Sarasota County Historical Preservation Board; 
(b)  The sign is a minimum of 25 years old; 
(c)  The sign is unique and enhances the cultural, historical or aesthetic quality of the community; 
(d)  The sign is structurally and electrically safe or is capable of being made so without substantially altering its historical significance; and 
(e)  The sign is of exemplary technology, craftsmanship, or design of the period in which it was constructed, uses historic sign materials, and is not significantly altered from its historic period. If the sign has been altered, it shall be restored to its historic function and appearance. 
(2)  Modifications. Historical signs are not permitted be modified, removed, or replaced unless approved by the town commission. 
(3)  Abandonment. Notwithstanding subsection (2) above, any historical sign located on a premises that has been vacated for six consecutive months shall be allowed to remain in place if all copy on the sign face is removed except for the site address and the sign is maintained in accordance with subsection 156.10(A)(4). 
(Ord. 2017-03, passed 7-9-18) 
156.08 - Variances. 
(A)  Variance authorized. The zoning board of adjustment may grant variances from the regulations contained in this chapter as follows: 
(1)  To permit a setback for a sign that is up to 20 percent less than the required setback, and 
(2)  To permit the area or height of a sign to be increased by up to 20 percent more than the maximum height or area allowed. 
(B)  Approval standards. The zoning board of adjustment may grant a variance authorized by this section if it finds the sign variance requested is required [warranted] by special or unique hardship because of: 
(1)  Exceptional narrowness, shallowness, or shape of the premises; or 
(2)  Exceptional topographic conditions or physical features uniquely affecting the premises. 
(Ord. 2017-03, passed 7-9-18) 
156.09 - Nonconformity and modification. 
(A)  Except as provided herein, signs lawfully in existence on July 9, 2018, which do not conform to the provisions of this sign code, but which were in compliance with the applicable regulations at the time they were constructed, erected, affixed, or maintained shall be regarded as nonconforming. 
(B)  Change and modification. A nonconforming sign shall be brought into conformity with this chapter if it is altered, reconstructed, replaced, or relocated. A change in copy is not an alteration or replacement for purposes of this subsection. 
(C)  Maintenance. Nonconforming signs shall be maintained in working condition. Required maintenance includes replacing or repairing worn or damaged parts of a sign to assure its continued working condition, and is not a change or modification prohibited by subsection (A), above. 
(D)  Removal. Removal of a nonconforming sign, or replacement of a nonconforming sign with a conforming sign, is required when: 
(1)  A nonconforming sign, or a substantial part of a nonconforming sign, is blown down, destroyed, or for any reason or by any means taken down, altered, or removed. As used in this subsection, "substantial" means 50 percent or more of the entire sign; 
(2)  The condition of the nonconforming sign has deteriorated without maintenance required by this section; or the nonconforming sign or building it is mounted on is destroyed or damaged by a fire, flood, windstorm, or similar extraordinary event; and the cost of restoration of the sign to its condition immediately prior to such deterioration or event exceeds 50 percent of the cost of reconstruction of the sign; or 
(3)  A site plan is approved for a property with a nonconforming sign. 
(E)  Multiple signs. If a premises has more signs or sign area than this chapter allows, any sign in excess of that amount is nonconforming. 
(F)  Signs which were unlawful under the prior sign code and which do not conform to this sign code shall be removed immediately. 
(Ord. 2017-03, passed 7-9-18) 
156.10 - Maintenance and abandonment. 
(A)  Maintenance. 
(1)  Painting, repainting, cleaning, or other ordinary repairs and maintenance of any legal sign shall not require a permit. 
(2)  Replacement of any structural elements or items that extend or prolong the life of a sign shall require a permit. 
(3)  A sign permit issued by the town shall authorize the removal of a sign that is not properly maintained, including a sign which is not maintained in safe and good working order, or which was legally erected but which has been defaced, altered, or modified without prior town approval, at the joint and several expense of the sign owner, agent, and/or property owner. 
(4)  All signs, including their supports, braces, guys, and anchors, and associated landscaping shall be maintained so as to present a neat, clean appearance. Painted areas and sign surfaces shall be kept in good condition and illumination shall be maintained in safe and good working order. 
(B)  Signs on vacated properties. Any sign located on a premise that has been vacated for six consecutive months shall be removed by the sign owner, agent, or property owner. A legally conforming ground-mounted sign shall be allowed to remain in place if all signage and other displays are removed, except for the site address and the sign is maintained in accordance with subsection 156.10(A)(4). 
(Ord. 2017-03, passed 7-9-18) 
156.11 - Violations and sign removal. 
(A)  Signs in violation of this chapter are subject to the following notice and removal provisions, in addition to the enforcement procedures and penalties provided in section 156.12 of this chapter: 
Description of
Violation Notice/Penalties/Fees (1) Erection of nonexempt signs without a valid permit: (1) Immediate removal and disposition by the town without notice. (2) Temporary signs and exempt signs that are improperly erected or located: (2) Immediate removal after notice (actual or constructive); impounded by the town for a minimum of 30 days. Sign owner is permitted to recover the sign upon payment of removal and storage costs. After 30 days the sign is permitted to be disposed of by the town without recourse. (3) Permanent signs erected without a valid permit: (3) Notified by town and allowed ten days to correct violation. Failure to correct the violation subjects the sign to removal. (4) Permanent signs erected pursuant to valid permit, but improperly located or constructed: (4) Notified by town and allowed ten days to correct violation. Failure to correct the violation subjects the sign to removal.  
(B)  Unsafe signs. Should a sign be found to be unsafe, insecure, or improperly constructed, the owner or lessee shall be required to make it safe, secure, and of proper construction, or remove it, within 48 hours from the time of notification in writing from the town. If the notice is not complied with within the time specified, the town shall remove the sign at the expense of the owner or lessee. If repairing or removing the sign is delayed by circumstances beyond the control of the owner or lessee, the town may grant additional time for the repair or removal of the sign. 
(C)  Sign causing imminent danger of hazard. The town is permitted to remove immediately and without notice any sign which is an immediate hazard at the expense of the owner, agent, lessee, or other person having beneficial use of the sign, the sign contractor, or the owner or lessee of the land upon which the sign is located. 
(Ord. 2017-03, passed 7-9-18) 
156.12 - Enforcement and penalties. 
(A)  Any violation of this chapter may be enforced through civil fines and administrative proceedings, including but not limited to, code enforcement proceedings in accordance with chapter 33 of this Code, and by equitable or legal proceedings. Each day of any such violation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(B)  All permits are allowed to be withheld from any applicant concerning property upon which a violation of this chapter has occurred and has not been corrected. 
(Ord. 2017-03, passed 7-9-18) 
156.13 - Compliance with chapter 100, Marine Turtle Protection. 
(A)  Conflicts. Where conflicts exist between provisions in this chapter and the provisions of chapter 100, the provisions in chapter 100 shall prevail. 
(B)  Compliance. Any sign which is altered, relocated, or replaced shall be brought immediately into compliance with all provisions of chapter 100. 
(Ord. 2017-03, passed 7-9-18) 
APPENDIX: - SIGN CODE ILLUSTRATIONS

If located in a street intersection, no sign exceeding 30 inches in height above the established grade of the street at the property line shall be erected or maintained on any lot within the intersection visibility triangle, except that a freestanding sign shall be permitted in a median located with the intersecting street right-of-way, provided that the sign is setback a minimum of five fee from the street right-of-way.

The sign structure shall be no more than 16 square feet for a single tenant property and no more than 42 square feet for a multiple tenant property. The bottom of the sign face shall be no more than two feet above the base.

Chapter 157 - SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS[6] 
  
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Subdivision fees; temporary use permits, ch. 159 

General Provisions 

157.01 - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the Town of Longboat Key Subdivision Regulations. 
('71 Code, Appendix A, § 1.10) 
157.02 - Purpose; jurisdiction. 
(A)  The procedures and standards for the development and subdivision of real estate and for the surveying and platting thereof, adopted and prescribed by this chapter, are hereby found by the town to be necessary and appropriate to do the following: 
(1)  Protect the public health, safety, comfort, convenience, and general welfare of the residents. 
(2)  Encourage economically sound and stable land development. 
(3)  Assure the provision of adequate streets, utilities, and other facilities and services to new land developments in conformance with public improvement needs and plans for the town. 
(4)  Assure the adequate provision of safe and convenient traffic access and circulation, both vehicular and pedestrian, in new land developments. 
(5)  Assure equitable handling of all subdivision plats by providing uniform procedures and standards for observation both by the developers of land and the town. 
(B)  This chapter shall be considered to be minimum requirements, for the purpose of promoting the general public health, safety, comfort, convenience, and welfare of the people of the town. 
(C)  This chapter shall govern the subdivision of any and all lands located within the incorporated limits of the town. 
('71 Code, Appendix A, §§ 1.20, 2.10, 9.30) 
157.03 - Definitions. 
(A)  Except as specifically defined in subsection (B) below, all words used in this chapter have their customary dictionary definitions. Words in the present tense include the future; words in the singular include the plural number, and words in the plural include the singular; "building" includes "structure"; "shall" is mandatory and not directory; "may" is permissive. 
(B)  For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    "Access legal." The right, created by fee simple ownership, for an owner, or proposed owner to ingress and egress via automobile or other motorized vehicle from the premises to a public or private street built pursuant to these subdivision regulations. 
    "Agent." A person or firm which acts in the applicant's behalf in application filed under these regulations. 
    "Alley." A service street or right-of-way which affords only a secondary means of access to abutting property and is not intended for general traffic circulation. 
    "Applicant." The owner of land, or legally authorized agent, submitting an applicant pursuant to these regulations. 
    "Block." A group of lots, including a tier of lots, existing within well-defined and fixed boundaries, usually being an area surrounded by streets or other physical barriers and having an assigned number, letter, or other name through which it may be identified. 
    "Buildable lot area." Land located within the required front, rear, and side building setback lines as established by the applicable zoning regulations on which a structure may be positioned. 
    "Building setback line." A line across a lot establishing the minimum distance of required yard to be provided between the building and the street property lines, shorelines, or other boundaries of a building site and measured from the furthest protrusion of the building. 
    "Comprehensive plan." A plan, together with any amendments, for the development of the town, prepared by the local planning agency and adopted by the town commission, pursuant to F.S. ch. 163, as may be amended. 
    "Crosswalk." A right-of-way within a block dedicated to public use, intended primarily for pedestrians and from which motor-propelled vehicles are excluded, and which is designed to provide pedestrian access to adjacent roads, lots, or public use areas. 
    "Cul-de-sac." A street having one end open to traffic and being permanently terminated within the plat by a vehicular turnaround. 
    "Easement." A grant by the subdivider for the use by the public, a corporation, or persons, of a strip of land for public utilities, drainage, and other public purposes. 
    "Health agencies." The Manatee or Sarasota County Health Department, as applicable, and the department of environmental protection, as applicable, and in accordance with state law and the town ordinances and regulations. 
    "Lot." A portion of a subdivision or other parcel of land, however designated, intended as a single building site or unit for the transfer of ownership, or for separate use of another. A lot is for the purpose of development conforming to this Code and the zoning code. A lot shall require no variance from the town ordinances and regulations in order to construct a principal structure. 
(a)  "Corner lot." A lot abutting on two or more streets at their intersection. 
(b)  "Double frontage lot" or "through lot." An interior lot having frontage on two streets, other than a corner lot. 
(c)  "Interior lot." A lot other than a corner lot having frontage on one street. 
(d)  "Substandard lot" or "nonconforming lot." A parcel of land that has less than the minimum area or minimum dimensions required in the zone in which the lot is located. 
    "Lot depth." The distance measured by a straight line from the midpoint of the front lot line to its intersection with the midpoint of the rear lot line. 
    "Lot width." The distance between the side lot lines measured along the minimum street setback (yard) line as required for the district in which it is located. This measurement is illustrated for rectangular and non-rectangular lots in the appendix to chapter 157. 
    "Mean high-water line." The land contour line derived from the intersection of the land surface with a level plane at the elevation of mean high-water as established by the laws of Florida. 
    "Permanent control point (P.C.P.)" A reference monument which meets the requirements as established by F.S. ch. 177. 
    "Permanent reference/monument (P.R.M.)." A permanent reference monument which shall meet the requirements as established by F.S. ch. 177. 
    "Planning and zoning board." The legally constituted membership of the "planning and zoning board" of the town. 
    "Plat." A map indicating the subdivision or resubdivision of land intended to be filed for record, or developed as regulated elsewhere herein. 
(a)  "Final plat." A finished drawing of a subdivision showing completely and accurately all legal and surveying information and certifications necessary for recording. 
(b)  "Preliminary plat." A drawing which shows the proposed layout of a subdivision in sufficient detail to indicate clearly its workability, but not in final form for recording. 
    "Registered engineers." A professional engineer registered and licensed with the State of Florida and in good standing with the Florida Board of Engineering Examiners. 
    "Registered land surveyor." A professional land surveyor registered and licensed with the State of Florida and in good standing with the Florida Board of Engineering Examiners. 
    "Right-of-way." A strip of land acquired by reservation, dedication, forced dedication, presumption or condemnation and intended to be occupied by a road, cross walk, utility service, and/or other similar uses; generally the right of one to pass over the property of another. 
    "Roadside drainageway." A channel alongside a street or road for the purpose of drainage. 
(a)  "Roadside swale." A roadside drainageway which does not require a culvert for ordinary vehicular crossing. 
(b)  "Roadside ditch." A roadside drainageway which requires a culvert for ordinary vehicular crossing. 
    "Street." A public or private right-of-way for vehicular traffic whether designated as a street, highway, thoroughfare, parkway, avenue, road, boulevard, land, place, or otherwise designated. 
(a)  "Arterial streets." Thoroughfare routes intended to carry moderate to large volumes of traffic through or around major sections of the town and a part of or connecting to the highway thoroughfare network. 
(b)  "Collector streets." Those streets which carry intermediate volumes of traffic from minor or local streets to arterial streets, including the principal entrance streets of a residential development. 
(c)  "Highways." Those traffic routes officially designated as federal or state highway routes, also referred to as state primary and secondary roads. 
(d)  "Marginal access street" or "service street." Streets which are parallel to and adjacent to highways and arterial streets, and which provide access to abutting properties. These streets are designed to protect the highways and arterial streets from the danger created by numerous points of conflict by driveways and individual access to abutting properties. A marginal access street provides access to property on one side only. 
(e)  "Minor streets" or "local streets." Those streets, the primary function of which is to provide access and service to abutting properties, including access and services to residential, commercial, and public uses. 
(f)  "Width of street." The shortest distance between the parallel lines delineating the right-of-way of a street. 
    "Subdivider." Any person, individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, estate, or trust, or any group or combination of the foregoing acting as a unit, dividing or proposing to divide land so as to constitute a subdivision as defined below. 
    "Subdivision." Includes all divisions of a tract or parcel of land into three or more lots or parcels for the purposes of building development or recording a plat thereof in the public records of Manatee or Sarasota Counties. Included is any subdivision of land involving the dedication of a new street, alley, or any other public right-of-way or a change in existing streets, alleys, or any other public rights-of-way, or any division of land that results in three or more lots or parcels. However, public acquisition of land for streets, alleys, public rights-of-way, or highway purposes shall not be deemed a subdivision. "Subdivision" includes resubdivision of an existing plat and when appropriate to the context shall relate to the process of subdividing. 
    "Title certification." The certification which accompanies every plat of a subdivision submitted to the planning and zoning board. It shall consist of a title opinion by an attorney-at-law, licensed in the state, or a title insurance company policy confirming that the lands as described and shown on the plat are in the name of the person, persons, or organization executing the dedication as it is shown on the plat and that the developer has apparent title to the lands. The title opinion or policy shall also show all mortgages on the land to be platted. 
('71 Code, Appendix A, §§ 3.10, 3.20; Ord. 81-37, passed 11-4-81; Ord. 01-15, passed 12-3-01; Ord. 2013-20, passed 6-30-14; Ord. 2016-34, passed 1-9-17) 
157.04 - Approval required before utility services permitted. 
(A)  No public utility services shall be provided for any lot or building in a new subdivision until the subdivision is approved by the town. 
(B)  No private utility service, including electricity, gas, telephone, or water, shall be provided for any lot or building in a new subdivision until the subdivision is approved by the town. 
('71 Code, Appendix A, §§ 11.10, 11.20) 
Cross reference- Penalty, § 157.99 
157.05 - Approval required before issuance of licenses; permits. 
    No building, electrical, plumbing, or any other permits or licenses as may be required by the town for any construction shall be issued for any building on any lot in a subdivision, until the subdivision is approved by the town. The limitations under this section and section 157.04 are not intended to restrict installation of temporary buildings or utility services to serve as construction offices. 
('71 Code, Appendix A, § 11.30) 
157.06 - Compliance required for building permit. 
(A)  No building permit shall be issued for, and no building or other structure shall be erected on, any lot, tract, or parcel of real estate unless the lot, tract, or parcel has been subdivided according to the provisions of this chapter. However, any lot, tract, or parcel conveyed and with the deed recorded in the public records prior to the effective date of this chapter (November 6, 1974) is exempted from this provision. 
(B)  No building permit shall be issued, nor construction allowed, for the construction of more than one structure housing a permitted or permissible principal use on a lot, tract or parcel of real estate, unless the lot, tract or parcel: 
(1)  Has been subdivided according to the provisions of this chapter; or 
(2)  Is a condominium created in accordance with F.S. § 718.104, meeting all lot, yard, bulk, density/intensity and other requirements of chapters 150 through 159, the Code for the Town of Longboat Key; or 
(3)  Is part of a Planned Unit Development ("PUD") or Outline Development Plan ("ODP") approved for deviations from chapter 158, Zoning Code, lot, yard and bulk regulations. 
('71 Code, Appendix A, § 4.60; Ord. 81-37, passed 11-4-81; Amd. Ord. 94-11, passed 4-21-94; Amd. Ord. 01-15, passed 12-3-01) 
157.07 - Variances. 
(A)  The town commission may authorize a variance from these subdivision regulations when, in its opinion, based upon competent, substantial evidence, that an undue hardship may result from strict compliance. In granting any variance, the town commission shall prescribe only conditions that it deems necessary to or desirable for the public interest. In making its findings, as required below, the town commission shall take into account the nature of the proposed use of land and the existing use of land in the vicinity, the number of persons to reside or work in the proposed subdivision, and the probable effect of the proposed subdivision on traffic conditions in the vicinity. 
(B)  No variance shall be granted unless the town commission finds that all of the following conditions exist. 
(1)  There are special circumstances or conditions affecting the property such that the strict application of the provisions of this chapter would deprive the applicant of the reasonable use of his land. 
(2)  The variance is necessary for the preservation and enjoyment of a substantial property right of the petitioner. 
(3)  The granting of the variance will not be detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to other property in the territory in which the property is situated. 
('71 Code, Appendix A, § 10.10; Amd. Ord. 01-15, passed 12-3-01) 
157.08 - Amendments. 
    This chapter may be amended from time to time as deemed necessary. All amendments shall first be reviewed and acted on by the planning and zoning board. The planning and zoning board recommendation shall then be forwarded to the town commission for action. However, no amendment to this chapter shall become effective until after a public hearing on each amendment shall be held by the town commission. 
('71 Code, Appendix A, § 9.10) 
157.09 - Conflict with other regulations. 
    Where other laws, ordinances, or private restrictive covenants in recorded deeds or any other legally binding agreements impose greater restrictions and limitations than those provided in this chapter, the laws, ordinances, covenants, or agreements shall control. 
('71 Code, Appendix A, § 9.40) 
Plat Specifications 

157.15 - Preapplication plans and data. 
(A)  General subdivision information shall describe or outline the existing conditions of the site and the proposed development as necessary to supplement the drawings required in subsections (B) and (C) below. This information shall include data on land characteristics, available community facilities, and utilities information describing the subdivision proposal such as numbers of lots, typical lot widths and depths, business areas and other public areas, and proposed utilities and street improvements. 
(B)  The location map shall show the relationship of areas immediately surrounding the proposed subdivision, and shall include the development name and location, title, north arrow and date. 
(C)  The sketch plan shall show in simple but relatively accurate sketch form the proposed land usage and arterial and collector street configurations. 
('71 Code, Appendix A, § 6.10) 
157.16 - Preliminary plat specifications. 
(A)  The submittal for preliminary plat approval shall consist of the original and copies of the application in black or blueline prints on white background. The applicant shall include any other documents in sufficient number to meet the requirements of this chapter. 
(B)  The preliminary plat shall be clearly and legibly drawn to the specifications herein required. 
(C)  Every subdivision shall be given a name by which it shall be legally known. The name shall not be the same or in any way so similar to any name appearing on any recorded plat in Manatee or Sarasota Counties, as applicable, which may confuse or mislead the public as to the identity of the subdivision. The above sentence shall not apply where the subdivision is an additional unit or section by the same developer or his successors title or the same or adjacent property. Every subdivision name shall have legible lettering of the same size and type, including the words "section", "unit", "replat". Any change in a plat, except as provided in F.S. § 177.141, shall be labeled a "replat" in conformance with F.S. § 177.051. The name of the subdivision shall be shown in the dedication and shall coincide exactly with the subdivision name. 
(D)  Every plat or replat of a subdivision submitted for platting must be accompanied by: 
(1)  A boundary survey of the platted lands in accordance with the requirements outlined by F.S. § 177.041. The boundary survey must be performed and prepared under the responsible direction of a professional surveyor and mapper preceding the initial submittal of the plat to the town. 
(2)  A title opinion of an attorney at law licensed in Florida or a certification by an abstractor or a title company showing that the record title to the land as described and shown on the plat is in the name of the person, persons, corporation, or entity executing the dedication. The title opinion or certification shall also show all mortgages not satisfied or released of record nor otherwise terminated by law. 
(E)  The preliminary plat shall be drawn to a scale and on a sheet size as required for final plat submission and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Proposed name of subdivision. 
(2)  Date of current survey (six months or less prior to date of application), north point and graphic scale, source of data, date of plat drawing, and space for revision dates prepared by a registered surveyor. 
(3)  Location, size of subdivision in acres, and number of lots. 
(4)  Location sketch locating the subdivision in relation to the immediately surrounding area with regard to well-known landmarks such as major highways, waterways, or other landmarks. 
(5)  Name and delineation of former subdivision, if any or all of the area encompassed by the preliminary plat had been previously subdivided. 
(6)  Preliminary boundary lines of the entire tract to be subdivided eventually. 
(7)  Contour lines at six-inch intervals or as necessary based on 1929 sea level datum and referenced to established benchmarks. 
(8)  Natural features within the proposed subdivision and in an area within at least 300 feet beyond the boundary of the proposed subdivision, including drainage channels, bodies of water, existing vegetation, and other significant features. Poorly drained areas or areas subject to storm flooding shall be shown where appropriate. 
(9)  Cultural features within the proposed subdivision and in an area within at least 300 feet beyond the boundary of the proposed subdivision including right-of-way widths and names of existing and platted streets, bridges, easements, town and county lines, and other significant information. 
(10)  Preliminary layout, including lot lines with approximate dimensions, basic lot sizes, lot numbers, block letters, zoning designation, base flood elevation, FEMA designation, street and alley lines with proposed street names, right-of-way widths for public or private streets, sites reserved through covenants, easements, dedication, or otherwise for public or common uses, and all tracts designed for multifamily or commercial use. 
(11)  Preliminary layout for all utilities including. but not limited to, sites, easements, or other provisions for water supply and wastewater collection. 
(12)  Drainage and grading plan, with preliminary computations. 
(13)  Proposed unit division of stage development, if any, as proposed by the subdivider. 
(14)  All section lines and quarter section lines occurring in the map or plat shall be indicated by lines drawn on the map or plat, with appropriate words and figures. If the description is by metes and bounds, the point of beginning shall be indicated together with all bearings and distances of the boundary lines. If the platted lands are in a land grant or are not included in the subdivision or government surveys, then the boundaries are to be defined by metes and bounds and courses. The initial point in the description shall be tied to the nearest government corner, or other recorded and well-established corner. 
(15)  All contiguous properties shall be identified by the subdivision title, plat book, and page or, if unplatted, land shall be shown to controlling lines appearing on the earlier plat to permit an overlay to be made; the fact of its being a resubdivision shall be stated as a subtitle following the name of the subdivision wherever it appears on the plat. 
(16)  Street names as submitted to the post office in a proposed subdivision shall be submitted by the developer to the town manager at the preapplication conference for review prior to final street naming. 
(17)  Streetlighting plan. 
(18)  The town bulkhead line, erosion control line, and mean high-water line, whenever applicable. 
('71 Code, Appendix A, § 6.20; Amd. Ord. 01-15, passed 12-3-01) 
157.17 - Final plat specifications. 
(A)  Every final plat of a subdivision within the town shall be submitted in a manner and form in conformance with F.S. ch. 177, and the requirements of Manatee or Sarasota County, as applicable. 
(B)  After approval of the final plat, with proper certifications and signatures attached, the subdivider shall furnish the following prints when recording: 
(1)  Original on tracing cloth or stable base film. 
(2)  One blackline print. 
(C)  The final plat shall conform to the approved preliminary plat in all significant respects. It may constitute only that portion of the preliminary plat which the subdivider proposes to record and develop at any one time, provided that the portion represents a reasonable staging procedure acceptable to the town. The final plat shall contain the information as required by F.S. ch. 177. In addition the following information shall be considered necessary for all plats within the town: 
(1)  Name of subdivision and all street names. 
(2)  Name of owner or owners of record. 
(3)  Name of subdivider. 
(4)  Date of plat drawing, graphic scale, north point, and a boundary description that a surveyor can readily follow for purposes of resurvey with ties to government corners and permanent reference markers at all angles in boundary and accurate dimensions and bearings. 
(5)  Location of tract, acres, number of lots, and area of each lot (in square feet). 
(6)  Name and delineation of former subdivision if any or all of the final plat had been previously subdivided. 
(7)  Location sketch. 
(8)  The boundary lines of the subdivision with their accurate lengths and bearings and the exact location of the subdivision within the section or sections by means of accurate angle and distance ties to one boundary of the section. 
(9)  Sufficient survey data shall be shown to positively describe the bounds of every lot, block, street easement, and all other areas shown on the plat. Lot, block, street, and all other dimensions except to irregular boundaries, shall be shown to a minimum of hundredths of feet. All measurements shall refer to horizontal plane and in accordance with the definition of a foot adopted by the United States Bureau of Standards. 
(10)  Municipal, county, or government lot lines are to be shown from information available from the appropriate public agency. 
(11)  Exact locations, widths, and names of all streets and alleys within and immediately adjoining the plat and the exact location and widths of all crosswalks. 
(12)  Street centerlines showing bearings, radii, length of arcs, chords and chord bearings, and central angles of curves. 
(13)  Lot lines with distances to the nearest .01 foot, line bearing, necessary internal angles, arcs, central angles, chords and chord bearings, and radii of rounded corners. 
(14)  All contiguous properties shall be identified by subdivision title, plat book and page or, if unplatted, land shall be so designated. 
(15)  All section lines and quarter section lines occurring in the map or plat shall be indicated by lines drawn on the map or plat, with appropriate words and figures. If the description is by metes and bounds, the point of beginning shall be indicated together with all bearings and distances of the boundary lines. If the platted lands are in a land grant or are not included in the subdivision of government surveys, then the boundaries are to be defined by metes and bounds and courses. The initial point in the description shall be tied to the nearest government corner, or other recorded and well-established corner. 
(16)  Lots or sites numbered in numerical order and blocks, if any, lettered alphabetically. 
(17)  Natural and cultural features to be retained in the proposed subdivision, as itemized in subsections 157.16(D)(8) and (9). 
(18)  Locations, dimensions, and purposes of all rights-of-way and easements for drainage, utilities, and other purposes, including slope easements, if required, and any areas to be reserved, donated, or dedicated to public use or sites for other than residential use with notes stating their purpose or limitations; and areas to be reserved by deed covenant for common uses of all property owners. 
(19)  Permanent reference monuments shall be placed at each corner or change in direction on the boundary of the lands being platted. 
(20)  Place for certificates, easements, and other legal statements. 
(D)  The final plat shall be accompanied by a title opinion by an attorney-at-law, licensed in the state, or a title insurance company policy confirming that the lands as described and shown on the plat are in the name of the person, persons, or organization executing the dedication of streets or other lands as it is shown on the plat and that the developer has apparent title to the lands. The title opinion or policy shall also show all mortgages on the land to be platted. The plat shall be consented to by all mortgagees. 
(E)  Prior to final approval by the town, the plat shall be reviewed for conformity with F.S. ch. 177, by a professional surveyor and mapper either employed by or under contract to the town, the costs of which shall be borne by the legal entity offering the plat for recordation, and evidence of such review shall be placed on the plat. 
('71 Code, Appendix A, § 6.30; Amd. Ord. 01-15, passed 12-3-01) 
157.18 - Plat certificates. 
    Each final plat submitted to the town for approval shall carry the certificates as required by Sarasota or Manatee County as applicable. In addition, the following town-required certificates shall be printed thereon substantially as follows, but adjusted as appropriate, subject to town approval. 
(A)  Surveyor's certificate.
